verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:1
verses.text: 160 He says in what follows, And with the sun He endureth, and before the moon generations of generations.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:2
verses.text: And again another of the Prophets saith, Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Sion, shout, O daughter of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:3
verses.text: Behold! thy King cometh unto thee, just and having salvation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:4
verses.text: Kings are many; of which speakest thou, O Prophet? Give us a sign which other Kings have not.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:5
verses.text: If thou say, A king clad in purple, the dignity of the apparel has been anticipated.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:6
verses.text: If thou say, Guarded by spear-men, and sitting in a golden chariot, this also has been anticipated by others.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:7
verses.text: Give us a sign peculiar to the King whose coming thou announcest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:8
verses.text: And the Prophet maketh answer and saith, Behold! thy King cometh unto thee, just, and having salvation: He is meek, and riding upon an ass and a young foal, not on a chariot.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:9
verses.text: Thou hast a unique sign of the King who came.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:10
verses.text: Jesus alone of kings sat upon an unyoked foal, entering into Jerusalem with acclamations as a king.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:11
verses.text: And when this King is come, what doth He? Thou also by the blood of the covenant hast sent forth thy prisoners out of the pit wherein is no water.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:13
verses.text: But He might perchance even sit upon a foal: give us rather a sign, where the King that entereth shall stand.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:14
verses.text: And give the sign not far from the city, that it may not be unknown to us: and give us the sign plain before our eyes, that even when in the city we may behold the place.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:15
verses.text: And the Prophet again makes answer, saying: And His feet shall stand in that day upon the Mount of Olives which is before Jerusalem on the east.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:16
verses.text: Does any one standing within the city fail to behold the place?  12.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:17
verses.text: We have two signs, and we desire to learn a third.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:18
verses.text: Tell us what the Lord doth when He is come.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:19
verses.text: Another Prophet saith, Behold! our God, and afterwards, He will come and save us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:20
verses.text: Then the eyes of the blind shall be opened, and the ears of the deaf shall hear: then shall the lame man leap as an hart, and the tongue of the stammerers shall be distinct.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:21
verses.text: But let yet another testimony be told us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:22
verses.text: Thou sayest, O Prophet, that the Lord cometh, and doeth signs such as never were: what other clear sign tellest thou? The Lord Himself entereth into judgment with the elders of His people, and with the princes thereof.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:23
verses.text: A notable sign! The Master judged by His servants, the elders, and submitting to it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:25
verses.text: These things the Jews read, but hear not: for they have stopped the ears of their heart, that they may not hear.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:26
verses.text: But let us believe in Jesus Christ, as having come in the flesh and been made Man, because we could not receive Him otherwise.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:27
verses.text: For since we could not look upon or enjoy Him as He was, He became what we are, that so we might be permitted to enjoy Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:28
verses.text: For if we cannot look full on the sun, which was made on the fourth day, could we behold God its Creator? The Lord came down in fire on Mount Sinai, and the people could not bear it, but said to Moses, Speak thou with us, and we will hear; and let not God speak to us, lest we die: and again, For who is there of all flesh that hath heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the midst of the fire, and shall live? If to hear the voice of God speaking is a cause of death, how shall not the sight of God Himself bring death? And what wonder? Even Moses himself saith, I exceedingly fear and quake.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:30
verses.text: What wouldest thou then? That He who came for our salvation should become a minister of destruction because men could not bear Him? or that He should suit His grace to our measure? Daniel could not bear the vision of an Angel, and wert thou capable of the sight of the Lord of Angels? Gabriel appeared, and Daniel fell down: and of what nature or in what guise was he that appeared? His countenance was like lightning; not like the sun: and his eyes as lamps of fire, not as a furnace of fire: and the voice of his words as the voice of a multitude, not as the voice of twelve legions of angels; nevertheless the Prophet fell down.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:31
verses.text: And the Angel cometh unto him, saying, Fear not, Daniel, stand upright: be of good courage, thy words are heard.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:32
verses.text: And Daniel says, I stood up trembling: and not even so did he make answer, until the likeness of a man's hand touched him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:33
verses.text: And when he that appeared was changed into the appearance of a man, then Daniel spoke: and what saith he? O my Lord, at the vision of Thee my inward parts were turned within me, and no strength remaineth in me, neither is there breath left in me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:34
verses.text: If an Angel appearing took away the Prophet's voice and strength, would the appearance of God have allowed him to breathe? And until there touched me as it were a vision of a man, saith the Scripture, Daniel took not courage.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:35
verses.text: So then after trial shewn of our weakness, the Lord assumed that which man required: for since man required to hear from one of like countenance, the Saviour took on Him the nature of like affections, that men might be the more easily instructed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:37
verses.text: Learn also another cause.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:38
verses.text: Christ came that He might be baptized, and might sanctify Baptism: He came that He might work wonders, walking upon the waters of the sea.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:39
verses.text: Since then before His appearance in flesh, the sea saw Him and fled, and Jordan was turned back, the Lord took to Himself His body, that the sea might endure the sight, and Jordan receive Him without fear.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:40
verses.text: This then is one cause; but there is also a second.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:41
verses.text: Through Eve yet virgin came death; through a virgin, or rather from a virgin, must the Life appear: that as the serpent beguiled the one, so to the other Gabriel might bring good tidings.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:42
verses.text: Men forsook God, and made carved images of men.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:43
verses.text: Since therefore an image of man was falsely worshipped as God, God became truly Man, that the falsehood might be done away.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:44
verses.text: The Devil had used the flesh as an instrument against us; and Paul knowing this, saith, But I see another law in my members warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity, and the rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:45
verses.text: By the very same weapons, therefore, wherewith the Devil used to vanquish us, have we been saved.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:46
verses.text: The Lord took on Him from us our likeness, that He might save man's nature: He took our likeness, that He might give greater grace to that which lacked; that sinful humanity might become partaker of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:47
verses.text: For where sin abounded, grace did much more abound.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:48
verses.text: It behoved the Lord to suffer for us; but if the Devil had known Him, he would not have dared to approach Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:49
verses.text: For had they known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of Glory.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:50
verses.text: His body therefore was made a bait to death that the dragon, hoping to devour it, might disgorge those also who had been already devoured.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:51
verses.text: For Death prevailed and devoured; and again, God wiped away every tear from off every face.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:53
verses.text: Was it without reason that Christ was made Man? Are our teachings ingenious phrases and human subtleties? Are not the Holy Scriptures our salvation? Are not the predictions of the Prophets? Keep then, I pray thee, this deposit undisturbed, and let none remove thee: believe that God became Man.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:54
verses.text: But though it has been proved possible for Him to be made Man, yet if the Jews still disbelieve, let us hold this forth to them: What strange thing do we announce in saying that God was made Man, when yourselves say that Abraham received the Lord as a guest? What strange thing do we announce, when Jacob says, For I have seen God face to face, and my life is preserved? The Lord, who ate with Abraham, ate also with us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:55
verses.text: What strange thing then do we announce? Nay more, we produce two witnesses, those who stood before Lord on Mount Sinai: Moses was in a clift of the rock, and Elias was once in a clift of the rock: they being present with Him at His Transfiguration on Mount Tabor, spoke to the Disciples of His decease which fire should accomplish at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:56
verses.text: But, as I said before, it has been proved possible for Him to be made man: and the rest of the proofs may be left for the studious to collect.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:58
verses.text: My statement, however, promised to declare also the time of the Saviour's and the place: and I must not go away convicted of falsehood, but rather send away the Church's novices well assured.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:59
verses.text: Let us therefore inquire the time when our Lord came: because His coming is recent, and is disputed: and because Christ Jesus is the same yesterday, and to-day, and for ever.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:60
verses.text: Moses then, the prophet, saith, A Prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me: but let that "like unto me" be reserved awhile to be examined in its proper place.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:61
verses.text: But when cometh this Prophet that is expected? Recur, he says, to what has been written by me: examine carefully Jacob's prophecy addressed to Judah: Judah, thee may thy brethren praise, and afterwards, not to quote the whole, A prince shall not fail out of Judah, nor a ruler from his loins, until He come, for whom it is reserved; and He is the expectation, not of the Jews but of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:62
verses.text: He gave, therefore, as a sign of Christ's advent the cessation of the Jewish rule.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:63
verses.text: If they are not now under the Romans, the Christ is not yet come: if they still have a prince of the race of Judah and of David, he is not yet come that was expected.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:64
verses.text: For I am ashamed to tell of their recent doings concerning those who are now called Patriarchs among them, and what their descent is, and who their mother: but I leave it to those who know.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:65
verses.text: But He that cometh as the expectation of the Gentiles, what further sign then hath He? He says next, Binding his foal unto the vine.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:66
verses.text: Thou seest that foal which was clearly announced by Zachariah.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:68
verses.text: But again thou askest yet another testimony of the time.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:69
verses.text: The Lord said unto Me, Thou art My Son; this day have I begotten Thee: and a few words further on, Thou shalt rule them with a rod of iron.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:70
verses.text: I have said before that the kingdom of the Romans is clearly called a rod of iron; but what is wanting concerning this let us further call to mind out of Daniel.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:71
verses.text: For in relating and interpreting to Nebuchadnezzar the image of the statue, he tells also his whole vision concerning it: and that a stone cut out of a mountain without hands, that is, not set up by human contrivance, should overpower the whole world: and he speaks most clearly thus; And in the days of those kingdoms the God of heaven shall set up a kingdom, which shall never be destroyed, and His kingdom shall not be left to another people.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:73
verses.text: But we seek still more clearly the proof of the time of His coming.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:74
verses.text: For man being hard to persuade, unless he gets the very years for a clear calculation, does not believe what is stated.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:75
verses.text: What then is the season, and what the manner of the time? It is when, on the failure of the kings descended from Judah, Herod a foreigner succeeds to the kingdom? The Angel, therefore, who converses with Daniel says, and do thou now mark the words, And thou shalt know and understand: From the going forth of the word for making answer, and for the building of Jerusalem, until Messiah the Prince are seven weeks and three score and two weeks.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:76
verses.text: Now three score and nine weeks of years contain four hundred and eighty-three years.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:77
verses.text: He said, therefore, that after the building of Jerusalem, four hundred and eighty-three years having passed, and the rulers having failed, then cometh a certain king of another race, in whose time the Christ is to be born.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:78
verses.text: Now Darius the Mede built the city in the sixth year of his own reign, and first year of the 66th Olympiad according to the Greeks.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:79
verses.text: Olympiad is the name among the Greeks of the games celebrated after four years, because of the day which in every four years of the sun's courses is made up of the three (supernumerary) hours in each year.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:80
verses.text: And Herod is king in the 186th Olympiad, in the 4th year thereof.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:81
verses.text: Now from the 66th to the 186th Olympiad there are 120 Olympiads intervening, and a little over.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:82
verses.text: So then the 120 Olympiads make up 480 years: for the other three years remaining are perhaps taken up in the interval between the first and fourth years.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:83
verses.text: And there thou hast the proof according to the Scripture which saith, From the going forth of the word that Jerusalem be restored and built until Messiah the Prince are seven weeks and sixty-two weeks.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:84
verses.text: Of the times, therefore, thou hast for the present this proof, although there are also other different interpretations concerning the aforesaid weeks of years in Daniel.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:86
verses.text: But now hear the place of the promise, as Micah says, And thou, Bethlehem, house of Ephrathah, art thou little to be among the thousands of Judah? For out of thee shall come forth unto Me a ruler, to be governor in Israel: and His goings forth are front the beginning, from the days of eternity.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:87
verses.text: But assuredly as to the places, thou being an inhabitant of Jerusalem, knowest also beforehand what is written in the hundred and thirty-first psalm.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:88
verses.text: Lo! we heard of it at Ephrathah, we found it in the plains of the wood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:89
verses.text: For a few years ago the place was woody.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:90
verses.text: Again thou hast heard Habakkuk say to the Lord, When the years draw nigh, thou shalt be made known, when the time is come, thou shalt be shewn.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:91
verses.text: And what is the sign, O Prophet, of the Lord's coming? And presently he saith, In the midst of two lives shalt thou be known, plainly saying this to the Lord, "Having come in the flesh thou livest and diest, and after rising from the dead thou livest again".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:92
verses.text: Further, from what part of the region round Jerusalem cometh He? From east, or west, or north, or south? Tell us exactly.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:93
verses.text: And he makes answer most plainly and says, God shall come from Teman (now Teman is by interpretation 'south') and the Holy One from Mount Paran, shady, woody: what the Psalmist spake in like words, We found it in the plains of the wood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:95
verses.text: We ask further, of whom cometh He and how? And this Esaias tells us: Behold! the virgin shall conceive in her womb, and shall bring forth a Son, and they shall call His name Emmanuel.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:96
verses.text: This the Jews contradict, for of old it is their wont wickedly to oppose the truth: and they say that it is not written "the virgin," but "the damsel".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:97
verses.text: But though I assent to what they say, even so I find the truth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:98
verses.text: For we must ask them, If a virgin be forced, when does she cry out and call for helpers, after or before the outrage? If, therefore, the Scripture elsewhere says, The betrothed damsel cried, and there was none to save her, doth it not speak of a virgin?  But that you may learn more plainly that even a virgin is called in Holy Scripture a "damsel," hear the Book of the Kings, speaking of Abishag the Shunamite, And the damsel was very fair: for that as a virgin she was chosen and brought to David is admitted.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:100
verses.text: But the Jews say again, This was said to Ahaz in reference to Hezekiah.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:101
verses.text: Well, then, let us read the Scripture: Ask thee a sign of the Lord thy God, in the depth or in the height.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:102
verses.text: And the sign certainly must be something astonishing.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:103
verses.text: For the water from the rock was a sign, the sea divided, the sun turning back, and the like.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:104
verses.text: But in what I am going to mention there is still more manifest refutation of the Jews.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:105
verses.text: (I know that I am speaking at much length, and that my hearers are wearied: but bear with the fulness of my statements, because it is for Christ's sake these questions are moved, and they concern no ordinary matters.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:106
verses.text: ) Now as Isaiah spoke this in the reign of Ahaz, and Ahaz reigned only sixteen years, and the prophecy was spoken to him within these years, the objection of the Jews is refuted by the fact that the succeeding king, Hezekiah, son of Ahaz, was twenty-five years old when he began to reign: for as the prophecy is confined within sixteen years, he must have been begotten of Ahaz full nine years before the prophecy.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:107
verses.text: What need then was there to utter the prophecy concerning one who had been already begotten even before the reign of father Ahaz? For he said not, hath conceived, but "the virgin shall conceive," speaking as with foreknowledge.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:109
verses.text: We know then for certain that the Lord was to be born of a Virgin, but we have to shew of what family the Virgin was.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:110
verses.text: The Lord sware in truth unto David, and will not set it aside.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:111
verses.text: Of the fruit of body will I set upon thy throne: and again, seed will I establish for ever, and his throne as the days of heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:112
verses.text: And afterwards, Once have I sworn by My holiness that I will not lie unto David.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:113
verses.text: His seed shall endure for ever, and his throne as the sun before Me, and as the moon established for ever.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:114
verses.text: Thou seest that the discourse is of Christ, not of Solomon.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:115
verses.text: For Solomon's throne endured not as the sun.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:116
verses.text: But if any deny this, because Christ sat not on David's throne of wood, we will bring forward that saying, The Scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat: for it signifies not his wooden seat, but the authority of his teaching.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:117
verses.text: In like manner then I would have you seek for David's throne not the throne of wood, but the kingdom itself.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:118
verses.text: Take, too, as my witnesses the children who cried aloud,Hosanna to the Son of David, blessed is the King of Israel.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:119
verses.text: And the blind men also say, Son of David, have mercy on us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:120
verses.text: Gabriel too testifies plainly to Mary, saying, And the Lord God shall give unto Him the throne of His father David.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:121
verses.text: Paul also saith, Remember Jesus Christ raised from the dead, of the seed of David, according to my Gospel: and in the beginning of the Epistle to the Romans he saith, Which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:122
verses.text: Receive thou therefore Him that was born of David, believing the prophecy which saith, And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, and He that shall rise to rule over the Gentiles: in Him shall the Gentiles trust.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:124
verses.text: But the Jews are much troubled at these things.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:125
verses.text: This also Isaiah foreknew, saying, And they shall wish that they had been burnt with fire: for unto us a child is born (not unto them), unto us a Son is given.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:126
verses.text: Mark thou that at first He was the Son of God, then was given to us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:127
verses.text: And a little after he says, And of His peace there is no bound.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:128
verses.text: The Romans have bounds: of the kingdom of the Son of God there is no bound.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:129
verses.text: The Persians and the Medes have bounds, but the Son has no bound.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:130
verses.text: Then next, upon the throne of David, and upon his kingdom to order it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:131
verses.text: The Holy Virgin, therefore, is from David.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:133
verses.text: For it became Him who is most pure, and a teacher of purity, to have come forth from a pure bride-chamber.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:134
verses.text: For if he who well fulfils the office of a priest of Jesus abstains from a wife, how should Jesus Himself be born of man and woman? For thou, saith He in the Psalms, art He that took Me out of the womb.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:135
verses.text: Mark that carefully, He that took Me out of the womb, signifying that He was begotten without man, being taken from a virgin's womb and flesh.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:136
verses.text: For the manner is different with those who are begotten according to the course of marriage.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:138
verses.text: And from such members He is not ashamed to assume flesh, who is the framer of those very members.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:139
verses.text: But then who telleth us this? The Lord saith unto Jeremiah: Before I formed thee in the belly, I knew thee: and before thou camest forth out of the womb, I sanctified thee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:140
verses.text: If, then, in fashioning man He was not ashamed of the contact, was He ashamed in fashioning for His own sake the holy Flesh, the veil of His Godhead? It is God who even now creates the children in the womb, as it is written in Job, Hast thou not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like cheese? Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh, and hast knit me together with bones and sinews.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:141
verses.text: There is nothing polluted in the human frame except a man defile this with fornication and adultery.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:142
verses.text: He who formed Adam formed Eve also, and male and female were formed by God's hands.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:143
verses.text: None of the members of the body as formed from the beginning is polluted.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:144
verses.text: Let the mouths of all heretics be stopped who slander their bodies, or rather Him who formed them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:145
verses.text: But let us remember Paul's saying, Know ye not that your bodies are the temples of the Holy Ghost which is in you? And again the Prophet hath spoken before in the person of Jesus, My flesh is from them: and in another place it is written, Therefore will He give them up, until the time that she bringeth forth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:146
verses.text: And what is the sign? He tells us in what follows, She shall bring forth, and the remnant of their brethren shall return.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:147
verses.text: And what are the nuptial pledges of the Virgin, the holy bride? And I will betroth thee unto Me in faithfulness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:148
verses.text: And Elizabeth, talking with Mary, speaks in like manner: And blessed is she that believed; for there shall be a performance of those things which were told her from the Lord.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:150
verses.text: But both Greeks and Jews harass us and say that it was impossible for the Christ to be born of a virgin.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:151
verses.text: As for the Greeks we will stop their mouths from their own fables.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:152
verses.text: For ye who say that stones being thrown were changed into men, how say ye that it is impossible for a virgin to bring forth? Ye who fable that a daughter was born from the brain, how say ye that it is impossible for a son to have been born from a virgin's womb? Ye who falsely say that Dionysus was born from the thigh of your Zeus, how set ye at nought our truth? I know that I am speaking of things unworthy of the present audience: but in order that thou in due season mayest rebuke the Greeks, we have brought these things forward answering them from their own fables.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:154
verses.text: But those of the circumcision meet thou with this question: Whether is harder, for an aged woman, barren and past age, to bear, or for a virgin in the prime of youth to conceive? Sarah was barren, and though it had ceased to be with her after the manner of women, yet, contrary to nature, she bore a child.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:155
verses.text: If, then, it is against nature for a barren woman to conceive, and also for a virgin, either, therefore, reject both, or accept both.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:156
verses.text: For it is the same God who both wrought the one and appointed the other.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:157
verses.text: For thou wilt not dare to say that it was possible for God in that former case, and impossible in this latter.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:158
verses.text: And again: how is it natural for a man's hand to be changed in a single hour into a different appearance and restored again? How then was the hand of Moses made white as snow, and at once restored again? But thou sayest that God's will made the change.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:159
verses.text: In that case God's will has the power, and has it then no power in this case? That moreover was a sign concerning the Egyptians only, but this was a sign given to the whole world.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:160
verses.text: But whether is the more difficult, O ye Jews? For a virgin to bear, or for a rod to be quickened into a living creature? Ye confess that in the case of Moses a perfectly straight rod became like a serpent, and was terrible to him who cast it down, and he who before held the rod fast, fled from it as from a serpent; for a serpent in truth it was: but he fled not because he feared that which he held, but because he dreaded Him that had changed it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:161
verses.text: A rod had teeth and eyes like a serpent: do then seeing eyes grow out of a rod, and cannot a child be born of a virgin's womb, if God wills? For I say nothing of the fact that Aaron's rod also produced in a single night what other trees produce in several years.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:162
verses.text: For who knows not that a rod, after losing its bark, will never sprout, not even if it be planted in the midst of rivers? But since God is not dependent on the nature of trees, but is the Creator of their natures, the unfruitful, and dry, and barkless rod budded, and blossomed, and bare almonds.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:163
verses.text: He, then, who for the sake of the typical high-priest gave fruit supernaturally to the rod, would He not for the sake of the true High-Priest grant to the Virgin to bear a child?  29.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:164
verses.text: These are excellent suggestions of the narratives: but the Jews still contradict, and do not yield to the statements concerning the rod, unless they may be persuaded by similar strange and supernatural births.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:165
verses.text: Question them, therefore, in this way: of whom in the beginning was Eve begotten? What mother conceived her the motherless? But the Scripture saith that she was born out of Adam's side.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:166
verses.text: Is Eve then born out of a man's side without a mother, and is a child not to be born without a father, of a virgin's womb? This debt of gratitude was due to men from womankind: for Eve was begotten of Adam, and not conceived of a mother, but as it were brought forth of man alone.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:167
verses.text: Mary, therefore, paid the debt, of gratitude, when not by man but of herself alone in an immaculate way she conceived of the Holy Ghost by the power of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:169
verses.text: But let us take what is yet a greater wonder than this.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:170
verses.text: For that of bodies bodies should be conceived, even if wonderful, is nevertheless possible: but that the dust of the earth should become a man, this is more wonderful.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:171
verses.text: That clay moulded together should assume the coats and splendours of the eyes, this is more wonderful.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:172
verses.text: That out of dust of uniform appearance should be produced both the firmness of bones, and the softness of lungs, and other different kinds of members, this is wonderful.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:173
verses.text: That clay should be animated and travel round the world self moved, and should build houses, this is wonderful.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:174
verses.text: That clay should teach, and talk, and act as carpenter, and as king, this is wonderful.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:175
verses.text: Whence, then, O ye most ignorant Jews, was Adam made? Did not God take dust from the earth, and fashion this wonderful frame? Is then clay changed into an eye, and cannot a virgin bear a son.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:176
verses.text: Does that which for men is more impossible take place, and is that which is possible never to occur?  31.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:177
verses.text: Let us remember these things, brethren: let us use these weapons in our defence.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:178
verses.text: Let us not endure those heretics who teach Christ's coming as a phantom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:179
verses.text: Let us abhor those also who say that the Saviour's birth was of husband and wife; who have dared to say that He was the child of Joseph and Mary, because it is written, And he took unto him his wife.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:180
verses.text: For let us remember Jacob who before he received Rachel, said to Laban, Give me my wife.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:181
verses.text: For as she before the wedded state, merely because there was a promise, was called the wife of Jacob, so also Mary, because she had been betrothed, was called the wife of Joseph.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:182
verses.text: Mark also the accuracy of the Gospel, saying, And in the sixth month the Angel Gabriel was sent from God unto a city of Galilee, named Nazareth, to a virgin espoused to a man whose name was Joseph, and so forth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:183
verses.text: And again when the census took place, and Joseph went up to enrol himself, what saith the Scripture? And Joseph also went up from Galilee, to enrol himself with Mary who was espoused to him, being great with child.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:184
verses.text: For though she was with child, yet it said not "with his wife," but with her who was espoused to him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:185
verses.text: For God sent forth His Son, says Paul, not made of a man and a woman, but made of a woman only, that is of a virgin.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:186
verses.text: For that the virgin also is called a woman, we shewed before.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:187
verses.text: For He who makes souls virgin, was born of a Virgin.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:189
verses.text: But thou wonderest at the event: even she herself who bare him wondered at this.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:190
verses.text: For she saith to Gabriel, How shall this be to me, since I know not a man? But he says, The Holy Ghost shall came upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee: wherefore also the holy thing which is to be born shall be called the Son of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:191
verses.text: Immaculate and undefiled was His generation: for where the Holy Spirit breathes, there all pollution is taken away: undefiled from the Virgin was the incarnate generation of the Only-begotten.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:192
verses.text: And if the heretics gainsay the truth, the Holy Ghost shall convict them: that overshadowing power of the Highest shall wax wroth: Gabriel shall stand face to face against them in the day of judgment: the place of the manger, which received the Lord, shall put them to shame.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:193
verses.text: The shepherds, who then received the good tidings, shall bear witness; and the host of the Angels who sang praises and hymns, and said,  Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace among men of His good pleasure: the Temple into which He was then carried up on the fortieth day: the pairs of turtle-doves, which were offered on His behalf: and Symeon who then took Him up in his arms, and Anna the prophetess who was present.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:195
verses.text: Since God then beareth witness, and the Holy Ghost joins in the witness, and Christ says, Why do ye seek to kill me, a man who has told you the truth? let the heretics be silenced who speak against His humanity, for they speak against Him, who saith, Handle me, and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:196
verses.text: Adored be the Lord the Virgin-born, and let Virgins acknowledge the crown of their own state: let the order also of Solitaries acknowledge the glory of chastity for we men are not deprived of the dignity of chastity.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:197
verses.text: In the Virgin's womb the Saviour's period of nine months was passed: but the Lord was for thirty and three years a man: so that if a virgin glories because of the nine months, much more we because of the many years.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:199
verses.text: But let us all by God's grace run the race of chastity, young men and maidens, old men and children; not going after wantonness, but praising the name of Christ.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:200
verses.text: Let us not be ignorant of the glory of chastity: for its crown is angelic, and its excellence above man.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:201
verses.text: Let us be chary of our bodies which are to shine as the sun: let us not for short pleasure defile so great, so noble a body: for short and momentary is the sin, but the shame for many years and for ever.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:202
verses.text: Angels walking upon earth are they who practise chastity: the Virgins have their portion with Mary the Virgin.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:203
verses.text: Let all vain ornament be banished, and every hurtful glance, and all wanton gait, and every flowing robe, and perfume enticing to pleasure.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:204
verses.text: But in all for perfume let there be the prayer of sweet odour, and the practice of good works, and the sanctification of our bodies: that the Virgin-born Lord may say even of us, both men who live in chastity and women who wear the crown, I will dwell in them; and walk in them, and I will be their God, and they shall be My people.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 1:205
verses.text: To whom be the glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:1
verses.text: Lecture XIII.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:2
verses.text: On the words, Crucified and Buried.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:3
verses.text: Isaiah liii.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:4
verses.text: 1, 7  Who hath believed our report? and to whom is the arm of the Lord revealed?He is brought as a lamb to the slaughter, &c.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:6
verses.text: Every deed of Christ is a cause of glorying to the Catholic Church, but her greatest of all glorying is in the Cross; and knowing this, Paul says, But God forbid that I should glory, save in the Cross of Christ.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:7
verses.text: For wondrous indeed it was, that one who was blind from his birth should receive sight in Siloam; but what is this compared with the blind of the whole world? A great thing it was, and passing nature, for Lazarus to rise again on the fourth day; but the grace extended to him alone, and what was it compared with the dead in sins throughout the world? Marvellous it was, that five loaves should pour forth food for the five thousand; but what is that to those who are famishing in ignorance through all the world? It was marvellous that she should have been loosed who had been bound by Satan eighteen years: yet what is this to all of us, who were fast bound in the chains of our sins? But the glory of the Cross led those who were blind through ignorance into light, loosed all who were held fast by sin, and ransomed the whole world of mankind.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:9
verses.text: And wonder not that the whole world was ransomed; for it was no mere man, but the only-begotten Son of God, who died on its behalf.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:10
verses.text: Moreover one man's sin, even Adam's, had power to bring death to the world; but if by the trespass of the one death reigned over the world, how shall not life much rather reign by the righteousness of the One? And if because of the tree of food they were then cast out of paradise, shall not believers now more easily enter into paradise because of the Tree of Jesus? If the first man formed out of the earth brought in universal death, shall not He who formed him out of the earth bring in eternal life, being Himself the Life? If Phinees, when he waxed zealous and slew the evil-doer, staved the wrath of God, shall not Jesus, who slew not another, but gave up Himself for a ransom, put away the wrath which is against mankind?  3.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:11
verses.text: Let us then not be ashamed of the Cross of our Saviour, but rather glory in it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:12
verses.text: For the word of the Cross is unto Jews a stumbling-block, and unto Gentiles foolishness, but to us salvation: and to them that are perishing it is foolishness, but unto us which are being saved it is the power of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:13
verses.text: For it was not a mere man who died for us, as I said before, but the Son of God, God made man.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:14
verses.text: Further; if the lamb under Moses drove the destroyer far away, did not much rather the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world, deliver us from our sins? The blood of a silly sheep gave salvation; and shall not the Blood of the Only-begotten much rather save? If any disbelieve the power of the Crucified, let him ask the devils; if any believe not words, let him believe what he sees.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:15
verses.text: Many have been crucified throughout the world, but by none of these are the devils scared; but when they see even the Sign of the Cross of Christ, who was crucified for us, they shudder.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:16
verses.text: For those men died for their own sins, but Christ for the sins of others; for He did no sin, neither was guile found in His mouth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:17
verses.text: It is not Peter who says this, for then we might suspect that he was partial to his Teacher; but it is Esaias who says it, who was not indeed present with Him in the flesh, but in the Spirit foresaw His coming in the flesh.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:18
verses.text: Yet why now bring the Prophet only as a witness? take for a witness Pilate himself, who gave sentence upon Him, saying, I find no fault in this Man: and when he gave Him up, and had washed his hands, he said, I am innocent of the blood of this just person.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:19
verses.text: There is yet another witness of the sinlessness of Jesus,the robber, the first man admitted into Paradise; who rebuked his fellow, and said, "We receive the due reward of our deeds; but this man hath done nothing amiss; for we were present, both thou and I, at His judgment".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:21
verses.text: Jesus then really suffered for all men; for the Cross was no illusion, otherwise our redemption is an illusion also.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:22
verses.text: His death was not a mere show, for then is our salvation also fabulous.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:23
verses.text: If His death was but a show, they were true who said, We remember that that deceiver said, while He was yet alive, After three days I rise again.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:24
verses.text: His Passion then was real: for He was really crucified, and we are not ashamed thereat; He was crucified, and we deny it not, nay, I rather glory to speak of it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:25
verses.text: For though I should now deny it, here is Golgotha to confute me, near which we are now assembled; the wood of the Cross confutes me, which was afterwards distributed piecemeal from hence to all the world.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:26
verses.text: I confess the Cross, because I know of the Resurrection; for if, after being crucified, He had remained as He was, I had not perchance confessed it, for I might have concealed both it and my Master; but now that the Resurrection has followed the Cross, I am not ashamed to declare it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:28
verses.text: Being then in the flesh like others, He was crucified, but not for the like sins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:29
verses.text: For He was not led to death for covetousness, since He was a Teacher of poverty; nor was He condemned for concupiscence, for He Himself says plainly, Whosoever shall look upon a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already; not for smiting or striking hastily, for He turned the other cheek also to the smiter; not for despising the Law, for He was the fulfiller of the Law; not for reviling a prophet, for it was Himself who was proclaimed by the Prophets; not for defrauding any of their hire, for He ministered without reward and freely; not for sinning in words, or deeds, or thoughts, He who did no sin, neither was guile found in His mouth; who when He was reviled, reviled not again; when He suffered, threatened not; who came to His passion, not unwillingly, but willing; yea, if any dissuading Him say even now, Be it far from Thee, Lord, He will say again, Get thee behind Me, Satan.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:31
verses.text: And wouldest thou be persuaded that He came to His passion willingly? others, who foreknow it not, die unwillingly; but He spoke before of His passion: Behold, the Son of man is betrayed to be crucified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:32
verses.text: But knowest thou wherefore this Friend of man shunned not death? It was lest the whole world should perish in its sins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:33
verses.text: Behold, we go up to Jerusalem, and the Son of man shall be betrayed, and shall be crucified; and again, He stedfastly set His face to go to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:34
verses.text: And wouldest thou know certainly, that the Cross is a glory to Jesus? Hear His own words, not mine.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:35
verses.text: Judas had become ungrateful to the Master of the house, and was about to betray Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:36
verses.text: Having but just now gone forth from the table, and drunk His cup of blessing, in return for that drought of salvation he sought to shed righteous blood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:37
verses.text: He who did eat of His bread, was lifting up his heel against Him; his hands were but lately receiving the blessed gifts, and presently for the wages of betrayal he was plotting His death.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:38
verses.text: And being reproved, and having heard that word, Thou hast said, he again went out: then said Jesus, The hour is come, that the Son of man should be glorified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:39
verses.text: Seest thou how He knew the Cross to be His proper glory? What then, is Esaias not ashamed of being sawn asunder, and shall Christ be ashamed of dying for the world? Now is the Son of man glorified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:40
verses.text: Not that He was without glory before: for He was glorified with the glory which was before the foundation of the world.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:41
verses.text: He was ever glorified as God; but now He was to be glorified in wearing the Crown of His patience.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:42
verses.text: He gave not up His life by compulsion, nor was He put to death by murderous violence, but of His own accord.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:43
verses.text: Hear what He says: I have power to lay down My life, and I have power to take it again: I yield it of My own choice to My enemies; for unless I chose, this could  not be.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:44
verses.text: He came therefore of His own set purpose to His passion, rejoicing in His noble deed, smiling at the crown, cheered by the salvation of mankind; not ashamed of the Cross, for it was to save the world.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:45
verses.text: For it was no common man who suffered, but God in man's nature, striving for the prize of His patience.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:47
verses.text: But the Jews contradict this, ever ready, as they are, to cavil, and backward to believe; so that for this cause the Prophet just now read says, Lord, who hath believed our report? Persians believe, and Hebrews believe not; they shall see, to whom He was not spoken of, and they that have not heard shall understand, while they who study these things shall set at nought what they study.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:48
verses.text: They speak against us, and say, "Does the Lord then suffer? What? Had men's hands power over His sovereignty?" Read the Lamentations; for in those Lamentations, Jeremias, lamenting you, wrote what is worthy of lamentations.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:49
verses.text: He saw your destruction, he beheld your downfall, he bewailed Jerusalem which then was; for that which now is shall not be bewailed; for that Jerusalem crucified the Christ, but that which now is worships Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:50
verses.text: Lamenting then he says, The breath of our countenance, Christ the Lord was taken in our corruptions.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:51
verses.text: Am I then stating views of my own? Behold he testifies of the Lord Christ seized by men.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:52
verses.text: And what is to follow from this? Tell me, O Prophet.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:53
verses.text: He says, Of whom we said, Under His shadow we shall live among the nations.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:54
verses.text: For he signifies that the grace of life is no longer to dwell in Israel, but among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:56
verses.text: But since there has been much gainsaying by them, come, let me, with the help of your prayers, (as the shortness of the time may allow,) set forth by the grace of the Lord some few testimonies concerning the Passion.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:57
verses.text: For the things concerning Christ are all put into writing, and nothing is doubtful, for nothing is without a text.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:58
verses.text: All are inscribed on the monuments of the Prophets; clearly written, not on tablets of stone, but by the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:59
verses.text: Since then thou hast heard the Gospel speaking concerning Judas, oughtest thou not to receive the testimony to it? Thou hast heard that He was pierced in the side by a spear; oughtest thou not to see whether this also is written? Thou hast heard that He was crucified in a garden; oughtest thou not to see whether this also is written? Thou hast heard that He was sold for thirty pieces of silver; oughtest thou not to learn what prophet spake this? Thou hast heard that He was given vinegar to drink; learn where this also is written.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:60
verses.text: Thou hast heard that His body was laid in a rock, and that a stone was set over it; oughtest thou not to receive this testimony also from the prophet? Thou hast heard that He was crucified with robbers; oughtest thou not to see whether this also is written? Thou hast heard that He was buried; oughtest thou not to see whether the circumstances of His burial are anywhere accurately written? Thou hast heard that He rose again; oughtest thou not to see whether we mock thee in teaching these things? For our speech and our preaching is not in persuasive words of man's wisdom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:61
verses.text: We stir now no sophistical contrivances; for these become exposed; we do not conquer words with words, for these come to an end; but we preach Christ Crucified, who has already been preached aforetime by the Prophets.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:62
verses.text: But do thou, I pray, receive the testimonies, and seal them in thine heart.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:63
verses.text: And, since they are many, and the rest of our time is narrowed into a short space, listen now to a few of the more important as time permits; and having received these beginnings, be diligent and seek out the remainder.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:64
verses.text: Let not thine hand be only stretched out to receive, but let it be also ready to work.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:65
verses.text: God gives all things freely.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:66
verses.text: For if any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God who giveth, and he shall receive.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:67
verses.text: May He through your prayer grant utterance to us who speak, and faith to you who hear.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:69
verses.text: Let us then seek the testimonies to the Passion of Christ: for we are met together, not now to make a speculative exposition of the Scriptures, but rather to be certified of the things which we already believe.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:70
verses.text: Now thou hast received from me first the testimonies concerning the coming of Jesus; and concerning His walking on the sea, for it is written, Thy way is in the sea.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:71
verses.text: Also concerning divers cures thou hast on another occasion received testimony.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:72
verses.text: Now therefore I begin from whence the Passion began.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:73
verses.text: Judas was the traitor, and he came against Him, and stood, speaking words of peace, but plotting war.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:74
verses.text: Concerning him, therefore, the Psalmist says, My friends and My neighbours drew near against Me, and stood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:75
verses.text: And again, Their words were softer than oil, yet be they spears.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:76
verses.text: Hail, Master; yet he was betraying his Master to death; he was not abashed at His warning, when He said, Judas, betrayest than the Son of Man with a kiss? for what He said to him was just this, Recollect thine own name; Judas means confession; thou hast covenanted, thou hast received the money, make confession quickly.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:77
verses.text: O God, pass not over My praise in silence; for the mouth of the wicked, and the mouth of the deceitful, are opened against Me; they have spoken against Me with a treacherous tongue, they have compassed Me about also with words of hatred.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:78
verses.text: But that some of the chief-priests also were present, and that He was put in bonds before the gates of the city, thou hast heard before, if thou rememberest the exposition of the Psalm, which has told the time and the place; how they returned at evening, and hungered like dogs, and encompassed the city.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:80
verses.text: Listen also for the thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:81
verses.text: And I will say to them, If it be good in your sight, give me my price, or refuse, and the rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:82
verses.text: One price is owing to Me from you for My healing the blind and lame, and I receive another; for thanksgiving, dishonour, and for worship, insult.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:83
verses.text: Seest thou how the Scripture foresaw these things? And they weighed for My price thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:84
verses.text: How exact the prophecy! how great and unerring the wisdom of the Holy Ghost! For he said, not ten, nor twenty, but thirty, exactly as many as there were.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:85
verses.text: Tell also what becomes of this price, O Prophet! Does he who received it keep it? or does he give it back? and after he has given it back, what becomes of it? The Prophet says then, And I took the thirty pieces of silver, and cast them into the house of the Lord, into the foundry.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:86
verses.text: Compare the Gospel with the Prophecy: Judas, it says, repented himself, and cast down the pieces of silver in the temple, and departed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:88
verses.text: But now I have to seek the exact solution of this seeming discrepancy.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:89
verses.text: For they who make light of the prophets, allege that the Prophet says on the one hand, And I cast them into the house of the Lord, into the foundry, but the Gospel on the other hand, And they gave them for the potter's field.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:90
verses.text: Hear then how they are both true.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:91
verses.text: For those conscientious Jews forsooth, the high-priests of that time, when they saw that Judas repented and said, I have sinned, in that I have betrayed innocent blood, reply, What is that to us, see thou to that.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:92
verses.text: Is it then nothing to you, the crucifiers? but shall he who received and restored the price of murder see to it, and shall ye the murderers not see to it? Then they say among themselves, It is not lawful to cast them into the treasury, because it is the price of blood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:93
verses.text: Out of your own mouths is your condemnation; if the price is polluted, the deed is polluted also: but if thou art fulfilling righteousness in crucifying Christ, why receivest thou not the price of it? But the point of iniquity is this: how is there no disagreement, if the Gospel says, the potter's field, and the Prophet, the foundry? Nay, but not only people who are goldsmiths, or brass-founders, have a foundry, but potters also have foundries for their clay.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:94
verses.text: For they sift off the fine and rich and useful earth from the gravel, and separate from it the mass of the refuse matter, and temper the clay first with water, that they may work it with ease into the forms intended.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:95
verses.text: Why then wonderest thou that the Gospel says plainly the potter's field, whereas the Prophet spoke his prophecy like an enigma, since prophecy is in many places enigmatical?  12.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:96
verses.text: They bound Jesus, and brought Him into the hall of the High-priest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:97
verses.text: And wouldest thou learn and know that this also is written? Esaias says, Woe unto their soul, for they have taken evil counsel against themselves, saying, Let us bind the Just, for He is troublesome to us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:98
verses.text: And truly, Woe unto their soul! Let us see how Esaias was sawn asunder, yet after this the people was restored.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:99
verses.text: Jeremias was cast into the mire of the cistern, yet was the wound of the Jews healed; for the sin was less, since it was against man.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:100
verses.text: But when the Jews sinned, not against man, but against God in man's nature, Woe unto their soul!Let us bind the Just; could He not then set Himself free, some one will say; He, who freed Lazarus from the bonds of death on the fourth day, and loosed Peter from the iron bands of a prison? Angels stood ready at hand, saying, Let us burst their bands in sunder; but they hold back, because their Lord willed to undergo it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:101
verses.text: Again, He was led to the judgment-seat before the Elders; thou hast already the testimony to this, The Lord Himself will come into judgment with the ancients of His people, and with the princes thereof.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:103
verses.text: But the High-priest having questioned Him, and heard the truth, is wroth; and the wicked officer of wicked men smites Him; and the countenance, which had shone as the sun, endured to be smitten by lawless hands.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:104
verses.text: Others also come and spit on the face of Him, who by spittle had healed the man who was blind from his birth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:105
verses.text: Do ye thus requite the Lord? This people is foolish and unwise.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:106
verses.text: And the Prophet greatly wondering, says, Lord, who hath believed our report? for the thing is incredible, that God, the Son of God, and the Arm of the Lord, should suffer such things.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:107
verses.text: But that they who are being saved may not disbelieve, the Holy Ghost writes before, in the person of Christ, who says, (for He who then spake these things, was afterward Himself an actor in them,) I gave My back to the scourges; (for Pilate, when he had scourged Him, delivered Him to be crucified;) and My cheeks to smitings; and My face I turned not away from the shame of spittings; saying, as it were, "Though knowing before that they will smite Me, I did not even turn My cheek aside; for how should I have nerved My disciples against death for truth's sake, had I Myself dreaded this?" I said.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:108
verses.text: He that loveth his life shall lose it: if I had loved My life, how was I to teach without practising what I taught? First then, being Himself God, He endured to suffer these things at the hands of men; that after this, we men, when we suffer such things at the hands of men for His sake, might not be ashamed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:109
verses.text: Thou seest that of these things also the prophets have clearly written beforehand.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:110
verses.text: Many, however, of the Scripture testimonies I pass by for want of time, as I said before; for if one should exactly search out all, not one of the things concerning Christ would be left without witness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:112
verses.text: Having been bound, He came from Caiaphas to Pilate,is this too written? yes; And having bound Him, they led Him away as a present to the king of Jarim.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:113
verses.text: But here some sharp hearer will object, "Pilate was not a king," (to leave for a while the main parts of the question,) "how then having bound Him, led they Him as a present to the king?" But read thou the Gospel; When Pilate heard that He was of Galilee, he sent Him to Herod; for Herod was then king, and was present at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:114
verses.text: And now observe the exactness of the Prophet; for he says, that He was sent as a present; for the same day Pilate and Herod were made friends together, for before they were at enmity.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:115
verses.text: For it became Him who was on the eve of making peace between earth and heaven, to make the very men who condemned Him the first to be at peace; for the Lord Himself was there present, who reconciles the hearts of the princes of the earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:116
verses.text: Mark the exactness of the Prophets, and their true testimony.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:118
verses.text: Look with awe then at the Lord who was judged.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:119
verses.text: He suffered Himself to be led and carried by soldiers.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:120
verses.text: Pilate sat in judgment, and He who sitteth on the right hand of the Father, stood and was judged.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:121
verses.text: The people whom He had redeemed from the land of Egypt, and oftimes from other places, shouted against Him, Away with Him, away with Him, crucify Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:122
verses.text: Wherefore, O ye Jews? because He healed your blind? or because He made your lame to walk, and bestowed His other benefits? So that the Prophet in amazement speaks of this too, Against whom have ye opened your mouth, and against whom have ye let loose your tongue? and the Lord Himself says in the Prophets, Mine heritage became unto Me as a lion in the forest; it gave its voice against Me; therefore have I hated it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:123
verses.text: I have not refused them, but they have refused Me; in consequence thereof I say, I have forsaken My house.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:125
verses.text: When He was judged, He held His peace; so that Pilate was moved for Him, and said, Hearest Thou not what these witness against Thee? Not that He knew Him who was judged, but he feared his own wife's dream which had been reported to him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:126
verses.text: And Jesus held His peace.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:127
verses.text: The Psalmist says, And I became as a man that heareth not; and in whose mouth are no reproofs; and again, But I was as a deaf man and heard not; and as a dumb man that openeth not his mouth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:128
verses.text: Thou  hast before heard concerning this, if thou rememberest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:130
verses.text: But the soldiers who crowd around mock Him, and their Lord becomes a sport to them, and upon their Master they make jests.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:131
verses.text: When they looked on Me, they shaked their heads.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:132
verses.text: Yet the figure of kingly state appears; for though in mockery, yet they bend the knee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:133
verses.text: And the soldiers before they crucify Him, put on Him a purple robe, and set a crown on His head; for what though it be of thorns? Every king is proclaimed by soldiers; and Jesus also must in a figure be crowned by soldiers; so that for this cause the Scripture says in the Canticles, Go forth, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, and look upon King Solomon in the crown wherewith His mother crowned Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:134
verses.text: And the crown itself was a mystery; for it was a remission of sins, a release from the curse.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:136
verses.text: Adam received the sentence, Cursed is the ground in thy labours; thorns and thistles shall it bring forth to thee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:137
verses.text: For this cause Jesus assumes the thorns, that He may cancel the sentence; for this cause also was He buried in the earth, that the earth which had been cursed might receive the blessing instead of a curse.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:138
verses.text: At the time of the sin, they clothed themselves with fig-leaves; for this cause Jesus also made the fig-tree the last of His signs.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:139
verses.text: For when about to go to His passion, He curses the fig-tree, not every fig-tree, but that one alone, for the sake of the figure; saying, No more let any man eat fruit of thee; let the doom be cancelled.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:140
verses.text: And because they aforetime clothed themselves with fig-leaves, He came at a season when food was not wont to be found on the fig-tree.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:141
verses.text: Who knows not that in winter-time the fig-tree bears no fruit, but is clothed with leaves only? Was Jesus ignorant of this, which all knew? No, but though He knew, yet He came as if seeking; not ignorant that He should not find, but shewing that the emblematical curse extended to the leaves only.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:143
verses.text: And since we have touched on things connected with Paradise, I am truly astonished at the truth of the types.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:144
verses.text: In Paradise was the Fall, and in a Garden was our Salvation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:145
verses.text: From the Tree came sin, and until the Tree sin lasted.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:146
verses.text: In the evening, when the Lord walked in the Garden, they hid themselves; and in the evening the robber is brought by the Lord into Paradise.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:147
verses.text: But some one will say to me, "Thou art inventing subtleties; shew me from some prophet the Wood of the Cross; except thou give me a testimony from a prophet, I will not be persuaded.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:148
verses.text: Hear then from Jeremias, and assure thyself; I was like a harmless lamb led to be slaughtered; did I not know it? (for in this manner read it as a question, as I have read it; for He who said, Ye know that after two days comes the passover, and the Son of Man is betrayed to be crucified, did He not know?) I was like a harmless lamb led to be slaughtered; did I not know it? (but what sort of lamb? let John the Baptist interpret it, when he says, Behold the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:149
verses.text: ) They devised against Me a wicked device, saying(He who knows the devices, knew He not the result of them? And what said they?)Come, and let us place a beam upon His bread(and if the Lord reckon thee worthy, thou shalt hereafter learn, that His body according to the Gospel bore the figure of bread;)Come then, and let us place a beam upon His bread, and cut Him off out of the land of the living;(life is not cut off, why labour ye for nought?)And His name shall be remembered no more.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:150
verses.text: Vain is your counsel; for before the sun His Name abideth in the Church.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:151
verses.text: And that it was Life, which hung on the Cross, Moses says, weeping, And thy life shall be hanging before thine eyes; and thou shalt be afraid day and night, and thou shalt not trust thy life.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:152
verses.text: And so too, what was just now read as the text, Lord, who hath believed our report?  20.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:153
verses.text: This was the figure which Moses completed by fixing the serpent to a cross, that whoso had been bitten by the living serpent, and looked to the brasen serpent, might be saved by believing.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:154
verses.text: Does then the brazen serpent save when crucified, and shall not the Son of God incarnate save when crucified also? On each occasion life comes by means of wood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:155
verses.text: For in the time of Noe the preservation of life was by an ark of wood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:156
verses.text: In the time of Moses the sea, on beholding the emblematical rod, was abashed at him who smote it; is then Moses' rod mighty, and is the Cross of the Saviour powerless? But I pass by the greater part of the types, to keep within measure.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:157
verses.text: The wood in Moses' case sweetened the water; and from the side of Jesus the water flowed upon the wood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:159
verses.text: The beginning of signs under Moses was blood and water; and the last of all Jesus' signs was the same.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:160
verses.text: First, Moses changed the river into blood; and Jesus at the last gave forth from His side water with blood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:161
verses.text: This was perhaps on account of the two speeches, his who judged Him, and theirs who cried out against Him; or because of the believers and the unbelievers.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:162
verses.text: For Pilate said, I am innocent and washed his hands in water; they who cried out against Him said, His blood be upon us: there came therefore these two out of His side; the water, perhaps, for him who judged Him; but for them that shouted against Him the blood.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:163
verses.text: And again it is to be understood in another way; the blood for the Jews, and the water for the Christians: for upon them as plotters came the condemnation from the blood; but to thee who now believest, the salvation which is by water.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:164
verses.text: For nothing has been done without a meaning.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:165
verses.text: Our fathers who have written comments have given another reason of this matter.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:166
verses.text: For since in the Gospels the power of salutary Baptism is twofold, one which is granted by means of water to the illuminated, and a second to holy martyrs, in persecutions, through their own blood, there came out of that saving Side blood and water, to confirm the grace of the confession made for Christ, whether in baptism, or on occasions of martyrdom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:167
verses.text: There is another reason also for mentioning the Side.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:168
verses.text: The woman, who was formed from the side, led the way to sin; but Jesus who came to bestow the grace of pardon on men and women alike, was pierced in the side for women, that He might undo the sin.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:170
verses.text: And whoever will inquire, will find other reasons also; but what has been said is enough, because of the shortness of the time, and that the attention of my hearers may not become sated.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:171
verses.text: And yet we never can be tired of hearing concerning the crowning of our Lord, and least of all in this most holy Golgotha.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:172
verses.text: For others only hear, but we both see and handle.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:173
verses.text: Let none be weary; take thine armour against the adversaries in the cause of the Cross itself; set up the faith of the Cross as a trophy against the gainsayers.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:174
verses.text: For when thou art going to dispute with unbelievers concerning the Cross of Christ, first make with thy hand the sign of Christ's Cross, and the gainsayer will be silenced.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:175
verses.text: Be not ashamed to confess the Cross; for Angels glory in it, saying, We know whom ye seek, Jesus the Crucified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:176
verses.text: Mightest thou not say, O Angel, "I know whom ye seek, my Master?" But, "I," he says with boldness, "I know the Crucified".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:177
verses.text: For the Cross is a Crown, not a dishonour.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:179
verses.text: Now let us recur to the proof out of the Prophets which I spoke of.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:180
verses.text: The Lord was crucified; thou hast received the testimonies.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:181
verses.text: Thou seest this spot of Golgotha! Thou answerest with a shout of praise, as if assenting.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:182
verses.text: See that thou recant not in time of persecution.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:183
verses.text: Rejoice not in the Cross in time of peace only, but hold fast the same faith in time of persecution also; be not in time of peace a friend of Jesus, and His foe in time of wars.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:184
verses.text: Thou receivest now remission of thy sins, and the gifts of the King's spiritual bounty; when war shall come, strive thou nobly for thy King.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:185
verses.text: Jesus, the Sinless, was crucified for thee; and wilt not thou be crucified for Him who was crucified for thee? Thou art not bestowing a favour, for thou hast first received; but thou art returning a favour, repaying thy debt to Him who was crucified for thee in Golgotha.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:186
verses.text: Now Golgotha is interpreted, "the place of a skull".
