verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:187
verses.text: Who were they then, who prophetically named this spot Golgotha, in which Christ the true Head endured the Cross? As the Apostle says, Who is the Image of the Invisible God; and a little after, and He is the Head of the body, the Church.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:188
verses.text: And again, The Head of every man is Christ; and again, Who is the Head of all principality and power.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:189
verses.text: The Head suffered in "the place of the skull".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:190
verses.text: O wondrous prophetic appellation! The very name also reminds thee, saying, "Think not of the Crucified as of a mere man; He is the Head of all principality and power.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:191
verses.text: That Head which was crucified is the Head of all power, and has for His Head the Father; for the Head of the man is Christ, and the Head of Christ is God".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:193
verses.text: Christ then was crucified for us, who was judged in the night, when it was cold, and therefore a fire of coals was laid.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:194
verses.text: He was crucified at the third hour; and from the sixth  hour there was darkness until the ninth hour; but from the ninth hour there was light again.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:195
verses.text: Are these things also written? Let us inquire.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:196
verses.text: Now the Prophet Zacharias says, And it shall come to pass in that day, that there shall not be light, and there shall be cold and frost one day; (the cold on account of which Peter warmed himself;) And that day shall be known unto the Lord; (what, knew He not the other days? days are many, but this is the day of the Lord's patience, which the Lord made;)And that day shall be known unto the Lord, not day, and not night: what is this dark saying which the Prophet speaks? That day is neither day nor night? what then shall we name it? The Gospel interprets it, by relating the event.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:197
verses.text: It was not day; for the sun shone not uniformly from his rising to his setting, but from the sixth hour till the ninth hour, there was darkness at mid-day.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:198
verses.text: The darkness therefore was interposed; but God called the darkness night.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:199
verses.text: Wherefore it was neither day nor night: for neither was it all light, that it should be called day; nor was it all darkness, that it should be called night; but after the ninth hour the sun shone forth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:200
verses.text: This also the Prophet foretels; for after saying, Not day, nor night, he added, And at evening time it shall be light.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:201
verses.text: Seest thou the exactness of the prophets? Seest thou the truth of the things which were written aforetime?  25.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:202
verses.text: But dost thou ask exactly at what hour the sun failed? was it the fifth hour, or the eighth, or the tenth? Tell, O Prophet, the exact time thereof to the Jews, who are unwilling to hear; when shall the sun go down? The Prophet Amos answers, And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the Lord God, that the sun shall go down at noon (for there was darkness from the sixth hour;) and the light shall grow dark over the earth in the day".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:203
verses.text: What sort of season is this, O Prophet, and what sort of day? And I will turn your feasts into mourning; for this was done in the days of unleavened bread, and at the feast of the Passover: then afterwards he says, And I will make Him as the mourning of an Only Son, and those with Him as a day of anguish; for in the day of unleavened bread, and at the feast, their women were wailing and weeping, and the Apostles had hidden themselves and were in anguish.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:204
verses.text: Wonderful then is this prophecy.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:206
verses.text: But, some one will say, "Give me yet another sign; what other exact sign is there of that which has come to pass? Jesus was crucified; and He wore but one coat, and one cloak: now His cloak the soldiers shared among themselves, having rent it into four; but His coat was not rent, for when rent it would have been no longer of any use; so about this lots are cast by the soldiers; thus the one they divide, but for the other they cast lots.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:207
verses.text: Is then this also written? They know, the diligent chanters of the Church, who imitate the Angel hosts, and continually sing praises to God: who are thought worthy to chant Psalms in this Golgotha, and to say, They parted My garments among them, and upon My vesture they did cast lots.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:208
verses.text: The "lots" were what the soldiers cast.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:210
verses.text: Again, when He had been judged before Pilate, He was clothed in red; for there they put on Him a purple robe.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:211
verses.text: Is this also written? Esaias saith, Who is this that cometh from Edom? the redness of His garments is from Bosor; (who is this who in dishonor weareth purple? For Bosor has some such meaning in Hebrew.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:212
verses.text: ) Why are Thy garments red, and Thy raiment as from a trodden wine-press? But He answers and says, All day long have I stretched forth Mine hands unto a disobedient and gainsaying people.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:214
verses.text: He stretched out His hands on the Cross, that He might embrace the ends of the world; for this Golgotha is the very centre of the earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:215
verses.text: It is not my word, but it is a prophet who hath said, Thou hast wrought salvation in the midst of the earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:216
verses.text: He stretched forth human hands, who by His spiritual hands had established the heaven; and they were fastened with nails, that His manhood, which here the sins of men, having been nailed to the tree, and having died, sin might die with it, and we might rise again in righteousness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:217
verses.text: For since by one man came death, by One Man came also life; by One Man, the Saviour, dying of His own accord: for remember what He said, I have power to lay down My life, and I have power to take it again.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:219
verses.text: But though He endured these things, having come for the salvation of all, yet the people returned Him an evil recompense.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:220
verses.text: Jesus saith, I thirst,He who had brought forth the waters for them out of the craggy rock; and He asked fruit of the Vine which He had planted.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:221
verses.text: But what does the Vine? This Vine, which was by nature of the holy fathers, but of Sodom by purpose of heart;(for their Vine is of Sodom, and their tendrils of Gomorrah;)this Vine, when the Lord was athirst, having filled a sponge and put it on a reed, offers Him vinegar.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:222
verses.text: They gave Me also gall for My meat, and in My thirst, they gave Me vinegar to drink.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:223
verses.text: Thou seest the clearness of the Prophets' description.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:224
verses.text: But what sort of gall put they into My mouth? They gave Him, it says, wine mingled with myrrh.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:225
verses.text: Now myrrh is in taste like gall, and very bitter.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:226
verses.text: Are these things what ye recompense unto the Lord? Are these thy offerings, O Vine, unto thy Master? Rightly did the Prophet Esaias aforetime bewail you, saying, My well-beloved had a vineyard in a hill in a fruitful place; and (not to recite the whole) I waited, he says, that it should bring forth grapes; I thirsted that it should give wine; but it brought forth thorns; for thou seest the crown, wherewith I am adorned.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:227
verses.text: What then shall I now decree? I will command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:228
verses.text: For the clouds which are the Prophets were removed from them, and are for the future in the Church; as Paul says, Let the Prophets speak two or three, and let the others judge; and again, God gave in the Church, some, Apostles, and some, Prophets.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:229
verses.text: Agabus, who bound his own feet and hands, was a prophet.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:231
verses.text: Concerning the robbers who were crucified with Him, it is written, And He was numbered with the transgressors.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:232
verses.text: Both of them were before this transgressors, but one was so no longer.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:233
verses.text: For the one was a transgressor to the end, stubborn against salvation; who, though his hands were fastened, smote with blasphemy by his tongue.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:234
verses.text: When the Jews passing by wagged their heads, mocking the Crucified, and fulfilling what was written, When they looked on Me, they shaked their heads, he also reviled with them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:235
verses.text: But the other rebused the reviler; and it was to him the end of life and the beginning of restoration; the surrender of his soul a first share in salvation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:236
verses.text: And after rebuking the other, he says, Lord, remember me; for with Thee is my account.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:237
verses.text: Heed not this man, for the eyes of his understanding are blinded; but remember me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:238
verses.text: I say not, remember my works, for of these I am afraid.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:239
verses.text: Every man has a feeling for his fellow-traveller; I am travelling with Thee towards death; remember me, Thy fellow-wayfarer.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:240
verses.text: I say not, Remember me now, but, when Thou comest in Thy kingdom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:242
verses.text: What power, O robber, led thee to the light? Who taught thee to worship that despised Man, thy companion on the Cross? O Light Eternal, which gives light to them that are in darkness! Therefore also he justly heard the words, Be of good cheer; not that thy deeds are worthy of good cheer; but that the King is here, dispensing favours.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:243
verses.text: The request reached unto a distant time; but the grace was very speedy.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:244
verses.text: Verily I say unto thee, This day shalt thou be with Me in Paradise; because to-day thou hast heard My voice, and hast not hardened thine heart.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:245
verses.text: Very speedily I passed sentence upon Adam, very speedily I pardon thee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:246
verses.text: To him it was said, In the day wherein ye eat, ye shall surely die; but thou to-day hast obeyed the faith, to-day is thy salvation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:247
verses.text: Adam by the Tree fell away; thou by the Tree art brought into Paradise.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:248
verses.text: Fear not the serpent; he shall not cast thee out; for he is fallen from heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:249
verses.text: And I say not unto thee, This day shalt thou depart, but, This day shalt thou be with Me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:250
verses.text: Be of good courage: thou shalt not be cast out.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:251
verses.text: Fear not the flaming sword; it shrinks from its Lord.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:252
verses.text: O mighty and ineffable grace! The faithful Abraham had not yet entered, but the robber enters! Moses and the Prophets had not yet entered, and the robber enters though a breaker of the law.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:253
verses.text: Paul also wondered at this before thee, saying, Where sin abounded, there grace did much more abound.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:254
verses.text: They who had borne the heat of the day had not yet entered; and he of the eleventh hour entered.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:255
verses.text: Let none murmur against the goodman of the house, for he says, Friend, I do thee no wrong; is it not  lawful for Me to do what I will with Mine own? The robber has a will to work righteousness, but death prevents him; I wait not exclusively for the work, but faith also I accept.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:256
verses.text: I am come who feed My sheep among the lilies, I am come to feed them in the gardens.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:257
verses.text: I have found a sheep that was lost, but I lay it on My shoulders; for he believes, since he himself has said, I have gone astray like a lost sheep; Lord, remember me when Thou comest in Thy kingdom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:259
verses.text: Of this garden I sang of old to My spouse in the Canticles, and spoke to her thus.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:260
verses.text: I am come into My garden, My sister, My spouse; (now in the place where He was crucified was a garden;) and what takest Thou thence? I have gathered My myrrh; having drunk wine mingled with myrrh, and vinegar, after receiving which, He said, It is finished.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:261
verses.text: For the mystery has been fulfilled; the things that are written have been accomplished; sins are forgiven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:262
verses.text: For Christ being come an High-Priest of the good things to come, by the greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is to say, not of this creation, nor yet by the blood of goats and calves, but by His own blood, entered in once for all into the holy place, having obtained eternal redemption; for if the blood of bulls and of goats, and the ashes of an heifer, sprinkling the defiled, sanctifieth to the purifying of the flesh, how much more the blood of Christ? And again, Having therefore, brethren, boldness to enter into the holiest by the blood of Jesus, by a new and living way, which He hath consecrated for us, through the veil, that is to say, His flesh.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:263
verses.text: And because His flesh, this veil, was dishonoured, therefore the typical veil of the temple was rent asunder, as it is written, And, behold, the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom; for not a particle of it was left; for since the Master said, Behold, your house is left unto you desolate, the house brake all in pieces.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:265
verses.text: These things the Saviour endured, and made peace through the Blood of His Cross, for things in heaven, and things in earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:266
verses.text: For we were enemies of God through sin, and God had appointed the sinner to die.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:267
verses.text: There must needs therefore have happened one of two things; either that God, in His truth, should destroy all men, or that in His loving-kindness He should cancel the sentence.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:268
verses.text: But behold the wisdom of God; He preserved both the truth of His sentence, and the exercise of His loving-kindness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:269
verses.text: Christ took our sins in His body on the tree, that we by His death might die to sin, and live unto righteousness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:270
verses.text: Of no small account was He who died for us; He was not a literal sheep; He was not a mere man; He was more than an Angel; He was God made man.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:271
verses.text: The transgression of sinners was not so great as the righteousness of Him who died for them; the sin which we committed was not so great as the righteousness which He wrought who laid down His life for us,who laid it down when He pleased, and took it again when He pleased.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:272
verses.text: And wouldest thou know that He laid not down His life by violence, nor yielded up the ghost against His will? He cried to the Father, saying, Father, into Thy hands I commend My spirit; I commend it, that I may take it again.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:273
verses.text: And having said these things, He gave up the ghost; but not for any long time, for He quickly rose again from the dead.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:275
verses.text: The Sun was darkened, because of the Sun of Righteousness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:276
verses.text: Rocks were rent, because of the spiritual Rock.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:277
verses.text: Tombs were opened, and the dead arose, because of Him who was free among the dead; He sent forth His prisoners out of the pit wherein is no water.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:278
verses.text: Be not then ashamed of the Crucified, but be thou also bold to say, He beareth our sins, and endureth grief for us, and with His stripes we are healed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:279
verses.text: Let us not be unthankful to our Benefactor.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:280
verses.text: And again; for the transgression of my people was He led to death; and I will give the wicked for His burial, and the rich for His death.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:281
verses.text: Therefore Paul says plainly, that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures, and that He was buried, and that He hath risen again the third day according to the Scriptures.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:283
verses.text: But we seek to know clearly where He has been buried.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:284
verses.text: Is His tomb made with hands? Is it, like the tombs of kings, raised above the ground? Is the Sepulchre made of stones joined together? And what is laid upon it? Tell us, O Prophets, the exact truth concerning His tomb also, where He is laid, and where we shall seek Him? And they say, Look into the solid rock which ye have hewn.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:285
verses.text: Look in and behold.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:286
verses.text: Thou hast in the Gospels In a sepulchre hewn in stone, which was hewn out of a rock.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:287
verses.text: And what happens next? What kind of door has the sepulchre? Again another Prophet says, They cut off My life in a dungeon, and cast a stone upon Me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:288
verses.text: I, who am the Chief corner-stone, the elect, the precious, lie for a little time within a stoneI who am a stone of stumbling to the Jews, and of salvation to them who believe.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:289
verses.text: The Tree of life, therefore was planted in the earth, that the earth which had been cursed might enjoy the blessing, and that the dead might be released.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:291
verses.text: Let us not then be ashamed to confess the Crucified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:292
verses.text: Be the Cross our seal made with boldness by our fingers on our brow, and on everything; over the bread we eat, and the cups we drink; in our comings in, and goings out; before our sleep, when we lie down and when we rise up; when we are in the way, and when we are still.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:293
verses.text: Great is that preservative; it is without price, for the sake of the poor; without toil, for the sick; since also its grace is from God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:294
verses.text: It is the Sign of the faithful, and the dread of devils: for He triumphed over them in it, having made a shew of them openly; for when they see the Cross they are reminded of the Crucified; they are afraid of Him, who bruised the heads of the dragon.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:295
verses.text: Despise not the Seal, because of the freeness of the gift; out for this the rather honour thy Benefactor.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:297
verses.text: And if thou ever fall into disputation and hast not the grounds of proof, yet let Faith remain firm in thee; or rather, become thou well learned, and then silence the Jews out of the prophets, and the Greeks out of their own fables.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:298
verses.text: They themselves worship men who have been thunderstricken: but the thunder when it comes from heaven, comes not at random.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:299
verses.text: If they are not ashamed to worship men thunderstricken and abhorred of God, art thou ashamed to worship the beloved Son of God, who was crucified for thee? I am ashamed to tell the tales about their so-called Gods, and I leave them because of time; let those who know, speak.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:300
verses.text: And let all heretics also be silenced.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:301
verses.text: If any say that the Cross is an illusion, turn away from him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:302
verses.text: Abhor those who say that Christ was crucified to our fancy only; for if so, and if salvation is from the Cross, then is salvation a fancy also.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:303
verses.text: If the Cross is fancy, the Resurrection is fancy also; but if Christ be not risen, we are yet in our sins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:304
verses.text: If the Cross is fancy, the Ascension also is fancy; and if the Ascension is fancy, then is the second coming also fancy, and everything is henceforth unsubstantial.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:306
verses.text: Take therefore first, as an indestructible foundation, the Cross, and build upon it the other articles of the faith.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:307
verses.text: Deny not the Crucified; for, if thou deny Him, thou hast many to arraign thee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:308
verses.text: Judas the traitor will arraign thee first; for he who betrayed Him knows that He was condemned to death by the chief-priests and elders.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:309
verses.text: The thirty pieces of silver bear witness; Gethsemane bears witness, where the betrayal occurred; I speak not yet of the Mount of Olives, on which they were with Him at night, praying.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:310
verses.text: The moon in the night bears witness; the day bears witness, and the sun which was darkened; for it endured not to look on the crime of the conspirators.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:311
verses.text: The fire will arraign thee, by which Peter stood and warmed himself; if thou deny the Cross, the eternal fire awaits thee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:312
verses.text: I speak hard words, that thou may not experience hard pains.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:313
verses.text: Remember the swords that came against Him in Gethsemane, that thou feel not the eternal sword.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:314
verses.text: The house of Caiaphas will arraign thee, shewing by its present desolation the power of Him who was erewhile judged there.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:315
verses.text: Yea, Caiaphas himself will rise up against thee in the day of judgment, the very servant will rise up against thee, who smote Jesus with the palm of his hand; they also who bound Him, and they who led Him away.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:316
verses.text: Even Herod shall rise up against thee; and Pilate; as if saying, Why deniest thou Him who was slandered before us by the Jews, and whom we knew to have done no wrong? For I Pilate then washed my hands.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:317
verses.text: The false witnesses shall rise up against thee, and the soldiers who arrayed Him in the purple robe, and set on Him the crown of thorns, and crucified Him in Golgotha, and cast lots for His coat.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:318
verses.text: Simon the Cyrenian will cry out upon thee, who bore the Cross after Jesus.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:320
verses.text: From among the stars there will cry out upon thee, the darkened Sun; among the things upon earth, the Wine mingled with myrrh; among reeds, the Reed; among herbs, the Hyssop; among the things of the sea, the Sponge; among trees, the Wood of the Cross;the soldiers, too, as I have said, who nailed Him, and cast lots for His vesture; the soldier who pierced His side with the spear; the women who then were present; the veil of the temple then rent asunder; the hall of Pilate, now laid waste by the power of Him who was then crucified; this holy Golgotha, which stands high above us, and shews itself to this day, and displays even yet how because of Christ the rocks were then riven; the sepulchre nigh at hand where He was laid; and the stone which was laid on the door, which lies to this day by the tomb; the Angels who were then present; the women who worshipped Him after His resurrection; Peter and John, who ran to the sepulchre; and Thomas, who thrust his hand into His side, and his fingers into the prints of the nails.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:321
verses.text: For it was for our sakes that he so carefully handled Him; and what thou, who wert not there present, wouldest have sought, he being present, by God's Providence, did seek.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:323
verses.text: Thou hast Twelve Apostles, witnesses of the Cross; and the whole earth, and the world of men who believe on Him who hung thereon.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:324
verses.text: Let thy very presence here now persuade thee of the power of the Crucified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:325
verses.text: For who now brought thee to this assembly? what soldiers? With what bonds wast thou constrained? What sentence held thee fast here now? Nay, it was the Trophy of salvation, the Cross of Jesus that brought you all together.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:326
verses.text: It was this that enslaved the Persians, and tamed the Scythians; this that gave to the Egyptians, for cats and dogs and their manifold errors, the knowledge of God; this, that to this day heals diseases; that to this day drives away devils, and overthrows the juggleries of drugs and charms.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 2:328
verses.text: This shall appear again with Jesus from heaven; for the trophy shall precede the king: that seeing Him whom they pierced, and knowing by the Cross Him who was dishonoured, the Jews may repent and mourn; (but they shall mourn tribe by tribe, for they shall repent, when there shall be no more time for repentance;) and that we may glory, exulting in the Cross, worshipping the Lord who was sent, and crucified for us, and worshipping also God His Father who sent Him, with the Holy Ghost: To whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:1
verses.text: Lecture XIV.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:2
verses.text: On the Words, And Rose Again from the Dead on the Third Day, and Ascended into the Heavens, and Sat on the Right Hand of the Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:3
verses.text: 1 Cor.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:4
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:5
verses.text: 14  Now I make known unto you, brethren, the gospel which I preached unto you.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:6
verses.text: that He hath been raised on the third day according to the Scriptures, &c.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:7
verses.text: Rejoice, O Jerusalem, and keep high festival, all ye that love Jesus; for He is risen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:8
verses.text: Rejoice, all ye that mourned before, when ye heard of the daring and wicked deeds of the Jews: for He who was spitefully entreated of them in this place is risen again.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:9
verses.text: And as the discourse concerning the Cross was a sorrowful one, so let the good tidings of the Resurrection bring joy to the hearers.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:10
verses.text: Let mourning be turned into gladness, and lamentation to joy: and let our mouth be filled with joy and gladness, because of Him, who after His resurrection, said Rejoice.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:11
verses.text: For I know the sorrow of Christ's friends in these past days; because, as our discourse stopped short at the Death and the Burial, and did not tell the good tidings of the Resurrection, your mind was in suspense, to hear what you were longing for.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:12
verses.text: Now, therefore, the Dead is risen, He who was free among the dead, and the deliverer of the dead.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:13
verses.text: He who in dishonour wore patiently the crown of thorns, even He arose, and crowned Himself with the diadem of His victory over death.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:15
verses.text: As then we set forth the testimonies concerning His Cross, so come let us now verify the proofs of His Resurrection also: since the Apostle before us affirms, He was buried, and has been raised on the third day according to the Scriptures.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:16
verses.text: As an Apostle, therefore, has sent us back to the testimonies of the Scriptures, it is good that we should get full knowledge of the hope of our salvation; and that we should learn first whether the divine Scriptures tell us the season of His resurrection, whether it comes in summer or in autumn, or after winter; and from what kind of place the Saviour has risen, and what has been announced in the admirable Prophets as the name of the place of the Resurrection, and whether the women, who sought and found Him not, afterwards rejoice at finding Him; in order that when the Gospels are read, the narratives of these holy Scriptures may not be thought fables nor rhapsodies.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:18
verses.text: That the Saviour then was buried, ye have heard distinctly in the preceding discourse, as Isaiah saith, His burial shall be in peace: for in His burial He made peace between heaven and earth, bringing sinners unto God: and, that the righteous is taken out of the way of unrighteousness: and, His burial shall be in peace: and, I will give the wicked for His burial.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:19
verses.text: There is also the prophecy of Jacob saying in the Scriptures, He lay down and couched as a lion, and as a lion's whelp: who shall rouse Him up? And the similar passage in Numbers, He couched, He lay down as a lion, and as a lion's whelp.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:20
verses.text: The Psalm also ye have often heard, which says, And Thou hast brought me down into the dust of death.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:21
verses.text: Moreover we took note of the spot, when we quoted the words, Look unto the rock, which ye have hewn.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:22
verses.text: But now let the testimonies concerning His resurrection itself go with us on our way.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:24
verses.text: First, then, in the 11th Psalm He says, For the misery of the poor, and the sighing of the needy, now will I arise, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:25
verses.text: But this passage still remains doubtful with some: for He often rises up also in anger, to take vengeance upon His enemies.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:26
verses.text: Come then to the 15th Psalm, which says distinctly: Preserve Me, O Lord, for in Thee have I put my trust: and after this, their assemblies of blood will I not join, nor make mention of their names between my lips; since they have refused me, and chosen Caesar as their king: and also the next words, I foresaw the Lord alway before Me, because He is at My right hand, that I may not be moved: and soon after Yea and even until night my reins chastened me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:27
verses.text: And after this He says most plainly, For Thou wilt not leave My soul in hell; neither wilt Thou suffer Thine Holy One to see corruption.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:28
verses.text: He said not, neither wilt Thou suffer Thine Holy One to see death, since then He would not have died; but corruption, saith He, I see not, and shall not abide in death.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:29
verses.text: Thou hast made known to Me the ways of life.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:30
verses.text: Behold here is plainly preached a life after death.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:31
verses.text: Come also to the 29th Psalm, I will extol Thee, O Lord, for Thou hast lifted Me up, and hast not made My foes to rejoice over Me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:32
verses.text: What is it that took place? Wert thou rescued from enemies, or wert thou released when about to be smitten? He says himself most plainly, O Lord, Thou hast brought up My soul from hell.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:33
verses.text: There he says, Thou wilt not leave, prophetically: and here he speaks of that which is to take place as having taken place, Thou hast brought up.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:34
verses.text: Thou hast saved Me from them that go down into the pit.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:35
verses.text: At what time shall the event occur? Weeping shall continue for the evening, and joy cometh in the morning: for in the evening was the sorrow of the disciplines, and in the morning the joy of the resurrection.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:37
verses.text: But wouldst thou know the place also? Again He saith in Canticles, I went down into the garden of nuts; for it was a garden where He was crucified.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:38
verses.text: For though it has now been most highly adorned with royal gifts, yet formerly it was a garden, and the signs and the remnants of this remain.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:39
verses.text: A garden enclosed, a fountain sealed, by the Jews who said, We remember that that deceiver said while He was yet alive, After three days, I will rise: command, therefore, that the sepulchre be made sure; and further on, So they went, and made the sepulchre sure, sealing the stone with the guard.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:40
verses.text: And aiming well at these, one saith, and in rest Thou shalt judge them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:41
verses.text: But who is the fountain that is sealed, or who is interpreted as being a well-spring of living water? It is the Saviour Himself, concerning whom it is written, For with Thee is the fountain of life.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:43
verses.text: But what says Zephaniah in the person of Christ to the disciples? Prepare thyself, be rising at the dawn: all their gleaning is destroyed: the gleaning, that is, of the Jews, with whom there is not a cluster, nay not even a gleaning of salvation left; for their vine is cut down.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:44
verses.text: See how He says to the disciples, Prepare thyself, rise up at dawn: at dawn expect the Resurrection.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:45
verses.text: And farther on in the same context of Scripture He says, Therefore wait thou for Me, saith the Lord, until the day of My Resurrection at the Testimony.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:46
verses.text: Thou seest that the Prophet foresaw the place also of the Resurrection, which was to be surnamed "the Testimony".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:47
verses.text: For what is the reason that this spot of Golgotha and of the Resurrection is not called, like the rest of the Churches, a Church, but a Testimony? Why, perhaps, it was because of the Prophet, who had said, until the day of My Resurrection at the Testimony.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:49
verses.text: And who then is this, and what is the sign of Him that rises? In the words of the Prophet that follow in the same context, He says plainly, For then will I turn to the peoples a language: since, after the Resurrection, when the Holy Ghost was sent forth the gift of tongues was granted, that they might serve the Lord under one yoke.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:50
verses.text: And what other token is set forth in the same Prophet, that they should serve the Lord under one yoke? From beyond the rivers of Ethiopia they shall bring me offerings.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:51
verses.text: Thou knowest what is written in the Acts, when the Ethiopian eunuch came from beyond the rivers of Ethiopia.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:52
verses.text: When therefore the Scriptures tell both the time and the peculiarity of the place, when they tell also the signs which followed the Resurrection, have thou henceforward a firm faith in the Resurrection, and let no one stir thee from confessing Christ risen from the dead.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:54
verses.text: Now take also another testimony in the  87th Psalm, where Christ speaks in the Prophets, (for He who then spoke came afterwards among us): O Lord, God of My salvation, I have cried day and night before Thee, and a little, farther on, I became as it were a man without help, free among the dead.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:55
verses.text: He said not, I became a man without help; but, as it were a man without help.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:56
verses.text: For indeed He was crucified not from weakness, but willingly and His Death was not from involuntary weakness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:57
verses.text: I was counted with them that go down into the pit.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:58
verses.text: And what is the token? Thou hast put away Mine acquaintance far from Me (for the disciples have fled).

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:59
verses.text: Wilt Thou shew wonders to the dead? Then a little while afterwards: And unto Thee have I cried, O Lord; and in the morning shall my prayer come before Thee.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:60
verses.text: Seest thou how they shew the exact point of the Hour, and of the Passion and of the Resurrection?  9.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:61
verses.text: And whence hath the Saviour risen? He says in the Song of Songs: Rise up, come, My neighbour: and in what follows, in a cave of the rock! A cave of the rock He called the cave which was erewhile before the door of the Saviour's sepulchre, and had been hewn out of the rock itself, as is wont to be done here in front of the sepulchres.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:62
verses.text: For now it is not to be seen, since the outer cave was cut away at that time for the sake of the present adornment.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:63
verses.text: For before the decoration of the sepulchre by the royal munificence, there was a cave in the front of the rock.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:64
verses.text: But where is the rock that had in it the cave? Does it lie near the middle of the city, or near the walls and the outskirts? And whether is it within the ancient walls, or within the outer walls which were built afterwards? He says then in the Canticles: in a cave of the rock, close to the outer wall.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:66
verses.text: At what season does the Saviour rise? Is it the season of summer, or some other? In the same Canticles immediately before the words quoted He says, The winter is past, the rain is past and gone; the flowers appear on the earth; the time of the pruning is come.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:67
verses.text: Is not then the earth full of flowers now, and are they not pruning the vines? Thou seest how he said also that the winter is now past.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:68
verses.text: For when this month Xanthicus is come, it is already spring.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:69
verses.text: And this is the season, the first month with the Hebrews, in which occurs the festival of the Passover, the typical formerly, but now the true.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:70
verses.text: This is the season of the creation of the world: for then God said, Let the earth bring forth herbage of grass, yielding seed after his kind and after his likeness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:71
verses.text: And now, as thou seest, already every herb is yielding seed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:72
verses.text: And as at that time God made the sun and moon and gave them courses of equal day (and night), so also a few days since was the season of the equinox.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:73
verses.text: At that time God said, let us make man after our image and after our likeness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:74
verses.text: And the image he received, but the likeness through his disobedience he obscured.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:75
verses.text: At the same season then in which he lost this the restoration also took place.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:76
verses.text: At the same season as the created man through disobedience was cast out of Paradise, he who believed was through obedience brought in.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:77
verses.text: Our Salvation then took place at the same season as the Fall: when the flowers appeared, and the pruning was come.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:79
verses.text: A garden was the place of His Burial, and a vine that which was planted there: and He hath said, I am the vine! He was planted therefore in the earth in order that the curse which came because of Adam might be rooted out.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:80
verses.text: The earth was condemned to thorns and thistles: the true Vine sprang up out of the earth, that the saying might be fulfilled, Truth sprang up out of the earth, and righteousness looked down from heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:81
verses.text: And what will He that is buried in the garden say? I have gathered My myrrh with My spices: and again, Myrrh and aloes, with all chief spices.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:82
verses.text: Now these are the symbols of the burying; and in the Gospels it is said, The women came unto the sepulchre bringing the spices which they had prepared: Nicodemus also bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloes.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:83
verses.text: And farther on it is written, I did eat My bread with My honey: the bitter before the Passion, and the sweet after the Resurrection.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:84
verses.text: Then after He had risen He entered through closed doors: but they believed not that it was He: for they supposed that they beheld a spirit.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:85
verses.text: But He said, Handle Me and see.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:86
verses.text: Put your fingers into the print of the nails, as Thomas required.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:87
verses.text: And while they yet believed not for joy, and wondered, He said unto them, Have ye here anything to eat? And they gave Him a piece of a broiled fish and honeycomb.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:88
verses.text: Seest thou how that is fulfilled, I did eat My bread with My honey.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:90
verses.text: But before He entered through the closed doors, the Bridegroom and Suitor of souls was sought by those noble and brave women.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:91
verses.text: They came, those blessed ones, to the sepulchre, and sought Him Who had been raised, and the tears were still dropping from their eyes, when they ought rather to have been dancing with joy for Him that had risen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:92
verses.text: Mary came seeking Him, according to the Gospel, and found Him not: and presently she heard from the Angels, and afterwards saw the Christ.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:93
verses.text: Are then these things also written? He says in the Song of Songs, On my bed I sought Him whom my soul loved.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:94
verses.text: At what season? By night on my bed I sought Him Whom my soul loved: Mary, it says, came while it was yet dark.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:95
verses.text: On my bed I sought Him by night, I sought Him, and I found Him not.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:96
verses.text: And in the Gospels Mary says, They have taken away my Lord, and I know not where they have laid Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:97
verses.text: But the Angels being then present cure their want of knowledge; for they said, Why seek ye the living among the dead? He not only rose, but had also the dead with Him when He rose.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:98
verses.text: But she knew not, and in her person the Song of Songs said to the Angels, Saw ye Him Whom my soul loved? It was but a little that I passed from them (that is, from the two Angels), until I found Him Whom my soul loved.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:99
verses.text: I held Him, and would not let Him go.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:101
verses.text: For after the vision of the Angels, Jesus came as His own Herald; and the Gospel says, And behold Jesus met them, saying, All hail! and they came and took hold of His feet.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:102
verses.text: They took hold of Him, that it might be fulfilled, I will hold Him, and will not let Him go.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:103
verses.text: Though the woman was weak in body, her spirit was manful.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:104
verses.text: Many waters quench not love, neither do rivers drown it; He was dead whom they sought, yet was not the hope of the Resurrection quenched.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:105
verses.text: And the Angel says to them again, Fear not ye; I say not to the soldiers, fear not, but to you; as for them, let them be afraid, that, taught by experience, they may bear witness and say, Truly this was the Son of God; but you ought not to be afraid, for perfect love casteth out fear.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:106
verses.text: Go, tell His disciples that He is risen; and the rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:107
verses.text: And they depart with joy, yet full of fear; is this also written? yes, the second Psalm, which relates the Passion of Christ, says, Serve the Lord with fear, and rejoice unto Him with trembling;rejoice, because of the risen Lord; but with trembling, because of the earthquake, and the Angel who appeared as lightning.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:109
verses.text: Though, therefore, Chief Priests and Pharisees through Pilate's means sealed the tomb; yet the women beheld Him who was risen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:110
verses.text: And Esaias knowing the feebleness of the Chief Priests, and the women's strength of faith, says, Ye women, who come from beholding, come hither; for the people hath no understanding;the Chief Priests want understanding, while women are eye-witnesses.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:111
verses.text: And when the soldiers came into the city to them, and told them all that had come to pass, they said to them, Say ye, His disciples came by night, and stole Him away while we slept? Well therefore did Esaias foretell this also, as in their persons, But tell us, and relate to us another deceit.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:112
verses.text: He who rose again, is up, and for a gift of money they persuade the soldiers; but they persuade not the kings of our time.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:113
verses.text: The soldiers then surrendered the truth for silver; but the kings of this day have, in their piety, built this holy Church of the Resurrection of God our Saviour, inlaid with silver and wrought with gold, in which we are assembled; and embellished it with the treasures of silver and gold and precious stones.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:114
verses.text: And if this come to the governor's ears, they say, we will persuade him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:115
verses.text: Yea, though ye persuade the soldiers, yet ye will not persuade the world; for why, as Peter's guards were condemned when he escaped out of the prison, were not  they also who watched Jesus Christ condemned? Upon the former, sentence was pronounced by Herod, for they were ignorant and had nothing to say for themselves; while the latter, who had seen the truth, and concealed it for money, were protected by the Chief Priests.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:116
verses.text: Nevertheless, though but a few of the Jews were persuaded at the time, the world became obedient.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:117
verses.text: They who hid the truth were themselves hidden; but they who received it were made manifest by the power of the Saviour, who not only rose from the dead, but also raised the dead with Himself.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:118
verses.text: And in the person of these the Prophet Osee says plainly, After two days will He revive us, and in the third day we shall rise again, and shall live in His sight.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:120
verses.text: But since the disobedient Jews will not be persuaded by the Divine Scriptures, but forgetting all that is written gainsay the Resurrection of Jesus, it were good to answer them thus: On what ground, while you say that Eliseus and Elias raised the dead, do you gainsay the Resurrection of our Saviour? Is it that we have no living witnesses now out of that generation to what we say? Well, do you also bring forward witnesses of the history of that time.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:121
verses.text: But that is written;so is this also written: why then do ye receive the one, and reject the other? They were Hebrews who wrote that history; so were all the Apostles Hebrews: why then do ye disbelieve the Jews? Matthew who wrote the Gospel wrote it in the Hebrew tongue; and Paul the preacher was a Hebrew of the Hebrews; and the twelve Apostles were all of Hebrew race: then fifteen Bishops of Jerusalem were appointed in succession from among the Hebrews.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:122
verses.text: What then is your reason for allowing your own accounts, and rejecting ours, though these also are written by Hebrews from among yourselves.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:124
verses.text: But it is impossible, some one will say, that the dead should rise; and yet Eliseus twice raised the dead,when he was alive, and also when dead.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:125
verses.text: Do we then believe, that when Eliseus was dead, a dead man who was cast upon him and touched him, arose and is Christ not risen? But in that case, the dead man who touched Eliseus, arose, yet he who raised him continued nevertheless dead: but in this case both the Dead of whom we speak Himself arose, and many dead were raised without having even touched Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:126
verses.text: For many bodies of the Saints which slept arose, and they came out of the graves after His Resurrection, and went into the Holy City, (evidently this city, in which we now are,) and appeared unto many.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:127
verses.text: Eliseus then raised a dead man, but he conquered not the world; Elias raised a dead man, but devils are not driven away in the name of Elias.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:128
verses.text: We are not speaking evil of the Prophets, but we are celebrating their Master more highly; for we do not exalt our own wonders by disparaging theirs; for theirs also are ours; but by what happened among them, we win credence for our own.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:130
verses.text: But again they say, "A corpse then lately dead was raised by the living; but shew us that one three days dead can possibly arise, and that a man should be buried, and rise after three days".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:131
verses.text: If we seek for Scripture testimony in proof of such facts, the Lord Jesus Christ Himself supplies it in the Gospels, saying, For as Jonas was three days and three nights in the whale's belly; so shall the Son of man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:132
verses.text: And when we examine the story of Jonas, great is the force of the resemblance.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:133
verses.text: Jesus was sent to preach repentance; Jonas also was sent: but whereas the one fled, not knowing what should come to pass; the other came willingly, to give repentance unto salvation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:134
verses.text: Jonas was asleep in the ship, and snoring amidst the stormy sea; while Jesus also slept, the sea, according to God's providence, began to rise, to shew in the sequel the might of Him who slept.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:135
verses.text: To the one they said, Why art thou snoring? Arise, call upon thy God, that God may save us; but in the other case they say unto the Master, Lord, save us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:136
verses.text: Then they said, Call upon thy God; here they say, save Thou.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:137
verses.text: But the one says, Take me, and cast me into the sea; so shall the sea be calm unto you; the other, Himself rebuked the winds and the sea, and there was a great calm.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:138
verses.text: The one was cast into a whale's belly: but the other of His own accord went down thither, where the invisible whale of death is.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:139
verses.text: And He went down of His own accord, that death might cast up those whom he had devoured, according to that which is written, I will ransom them from the power of the grave; and from the hand of death I will redeem them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:141
verses.text: At this point of our discourse, let us consider whether is harder, for a man after having been buried to rise again from the earth, or for a man in the belly of a whale, having come into the great heat of a living creature, to escape corruption.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:142
verses.text: For what man knows not, that the heat of the belly is so great, that even bones which have been swallowed moulder away? How then did Jonas, who was three days and three nights in the whale's belly, escape corruption? And, seeing that the nature of all men is such that we cannot live without breathing, as we do, in air, how did he live without a breath of this air for three days? But the Jews make answer and say, The power of God descended with Jonas when he was tossed about in hell.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:143
verses.text: Does then the Lord grant life to His own servant, by sending His power with him, and can He not grant it to Himself as well? If that is credible, this is credible also; if this is incredible, that also is incredible.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:144
verses.text: For to me both are alike worthy of credence.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:145
verses.text: I believe that Jonas was preserved, for all things are possible with God; I believe that Christ also was raised from the dead; for I have many testimonies of this, both from the Divine Scriptures, and from the operative power even at this day of Him who arose,who descended into hell alone, but ascended thence with a great company; for He went down to death, and many bodies of the saints which slept arose through Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:147
verses.text: Death was struck with dismay on beholding a new visitant descend into Hades, not bound by the chains of that place.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:148
verses.text: Wherefore, O porters of Hades, were ye scared at sight of Him? What was the unwonted fear that possessed you? Death fled, and his flight betrayed his cowardice.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:149
verses.text: The holy prophets ran unto Him, and Moses the Lawgiver, and Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob; David also, and Samuel, and Esaias, and John the Baptist, who bore witness when he asked, Art Thou He that should come, or look we for another? All the Just were ransomed, whom death had swallowed; for it behoved the King whom they had proclaimed, to become the redeemer of His noble heralds.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:150
verses.text: Then each of the Just said, O death, where is thy victory? O grave, where is thy sting? For the Conqueror hath redeemed us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:152
verses.text: Of this our Saviour the Prophet Jonas formed the type, when he prayed out of the belly of the whale, and said, I cried in my affliction, and so on; out of the belly of hell, and yet he was in the whale; but though in the whale, he says that he is in Hades; for he was a type of Christ, who was to descend into Hades.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:153
verses.text: And after a few words, he says, in the person of Christ, prophesying most clearly, My head went down to the chasms of the mountains; and yet he was in the belly of the whale.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:154
verses.text: What mountains then encompass thee? I know, he says, that I am a type of Him, who is to be laid in the Sepulchre hewn out of the rock.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:155
verses.text: And though he was in the sea, Jonas says, I went down to the earth, since he was a type of Christ, who went down into the heart of the earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:156
verses.text: And foreseeing the deeds of the Jews who persuaded the soldiers to lie, and told them, Say that they stole Him away, he says, By regarding lying vanities they forsook their own mercy.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:157
verses.text: For He who had mercy on them came, and was crucified, and rose again, giving His own precious blood both for Jews and Gentiles; yet say they, Say that they stole Him away, having regard to lying vanities.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:158
verses.text: But concerning His Resurrection, Esaias also says, He who brought up from the earth the great Shepherd of the sheep; he added the word, great, lest He should be thought on a level with the shepherds who had gone before Him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:160
verses.text: Since then we have the prophecies, let faith abide with us.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:161
verses.text: Let them fall who fall through unbelief, since they so will; but thou hast taken thy stand on the rock of the faith in the Resurrection.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:162
verses.text: Let no heretic ever persuade thee to speak evil of the Resurrection.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:163
verses.text: For to this day the Manichees say, that, the resurrection of the Saviour was phantom-wise, and not real, not heeding Paul who says, Who was made of the seed of David according to the flesh; and again, By the resurrection of Jesus Christ our Lord from the dead.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:164
verses.text: And again he aims at them, and speaks thus, Say not in  thine heart, who shall ascend into heaven; or who shall descend into the deep? that is, to bring up Christ from the dead; and in like manner warning as he has elsewhere written again, Remember Jesus Christ raised from the dead; and again, And if Christ be not risen, then is our preaching vain, and your faith also vain.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:165
verses.text: Yea, and we are found false witnesses of God; because we testified of God that He raised up Christ, whom He raised not up.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:166
verses.text: But in what follows he says, But now is Christ risen from the dead, the first fruits of them that are asleep;And He was seen of Cephas, then of the twelve; (for if thou believe not the one witness, thou hast twelve witnesses;) then He was seen of above five hundred brethren at once; (if they disbelieve the twelve, let them admit the five hundred;) after that He was seen of James, His own brother, and first Bishop of this diocese.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:167
verses.text: Seeing then that such a Bishop originally saw Christ Jesus when risen, do not thou, his disciple, disbelieve him.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:168
verses.text: But thou sayest that His brother James was a partial witness; afterwards He was seen also of me Paul, His enemy; and what testimony is doubted, when an enemy proclaims it? "I, who was before a persecutor, now preach the glad tidings of the Resurrection".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:170
verses.text: Many witnesses there are of the Saviour's resurrection.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:171
verses.text: The night, and the light of the full moon; (for that night was the sixteenth;) the rock of the sepulchre which received Him; the stone also shall rise up against the face of the Jews, for it saw the Lord; even the stone which was then rolled away, itself bears witness to the Resurrection, lying there to this day.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:172
verses.text: Angels of God who were present testified of the Resurrection of the Only-begotten: Peter and John, and Thomas, and all the rest of the Apostles; some of whom ran to the sepulchre, and saw the burial-clothes, in which He was wrapped before, lying there after the Resurrection; and others handled His hands and His feet, and beheld the prints of the nails; and all enjoyed together that Breath of the Saviour, and were counted worthy to forgive sins in the power of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:173
verses.text: Women too were witnesses, who took hold of His feet, and who beheld the mighty earthquake, and the radiance of the Angel who stood by: the linen clothes also which were wrapped about Him, and which He left when He rose;the soldiers, and the money given to them; the spot itself also, yet to be seen;and this house of the holy Church, which out of the loving affection to Christ of the Emperor Constantine of blessed memory, was both built and beautified as thou seest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:175
verses.text: A witness to the resurrection of Jesus is Tabitha also, who was in His name raised from the dead; for how shall we disbelieve that Christ is risen, when even His Name raised the dead? The sea also bears witness to the resurrection of Jesus, as thou hast heard before.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:176
verses.text: The drought of fishes also testifies, and the fire of coals there, and the fish laid thereon.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:177
verses.text: Peter also bears witness, who had erst denied Him thrice, and who then thrice confessed Him; and was commanded to feed His spiritual sheep.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:178
verses.text: To this day stands Mount Olivet, still to the eyes of the faithful all but displaying Him Who ascended on a cloud, and the heavenly gate of His ascension.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:179
verses.text: For from heaven He descended to Bethlehem, but to heaven He ascended from the Mount of Olives; at the former place beginning His conflicts among men, but in the latter, crowned after them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:180
verses.text: Thou hast therefore many witnesses; thou hast this very place of the Resurrection; thou hast also the place of the Ascension towards the east; thou hast also for witnesses the Angels which there bore testimony; and the cloud on which He went up, and the disciples who came down from that place.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:182
verses.text: The course of instruction in the Faith would lead me to speak of the Ascension also; but the grace of God so ordered it, that thou heardest most fully concerning it, as far as our weakness allowed, yesterday, on the Lord's day; since, by the providence of divine grace, the course of the Lessons in Church included the account of our Saviour's going up into the heavens; and what was then said was spoken principally for the sake of all, and for the assembled body of the faithful, yet especially for thy sake.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:183
verses.text: But the question is, didst thou attend to what was said? For thou knowest that the words which come next in the Creed teach thee to believe in Him "Who rose again the third day, and ascended into Heaven, and sat down on the right hand of the Father".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:184
verses.text: I suppose then certainly that thou rememberest the exposition; yet I will now again cursorily put thee in mind of what was then said.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:185
verses.text: Remember what is distinctly written in the Psalms, God is gone up with a shout; remember that the divine powers also said to one another, Lift up your gates, ye Princes, and the rest; remember also the Psalm which says, He ascended on high, He led captivity captive; remember the Prophet who said, Who buildeth His ascension unto heaven; and all the other particulars mentioned yesterday because of the gainsaying of the Jews.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:187
verses.text: For when they speak against the ascension of the Saviour, as being impossible, remember the account of the carrying away of Habakkuk: for if Habakkuk was transported by an Angel, being carried by the hair of his head, much rather was the Lord of both Prophets and Angels, able by His own power to make His ascent into the Heavens on a cloud from the Mount of Olives.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:188
verses.text: Wonders like this thou mayest call to mind, but reserve the preeminence for the Lord, the Worker of wonders; for the others were borne up, but He bears up all things.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:189
verses.text: Remember that Enoch was translated; but Jesus ascended: remember what was said yesterday concerning Elias, that Elias was taken up in a chariot of fire; but that the chariots of Christ are ten thousand-fold even thousands upon thousands: and that Elias was taken up, towards the east of Jordan; but that Christ ascended at the east of the brook Cedron: and that Elias went as into heaven; but Jesus, into heaven: and that Elias said that a double portion in the Holy Spirit should be given to his holy disciple; but that Christ granted to His own disciples so great enjoyment of the grace of the Holy Ghost, as not only to have It in themselves, but also, by the laying on of their hands, to impart the fellowship of It to them who believed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:191
verses.text: And when thou hast thus wrestled against the Jews,when thou hast worsted them by parallel instances, then come further to the pre-eminence of the Saviour's glory; namely, that they were the servants, but He the Son of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:192
verses.text: And thus thou wilt be reminded of His pre-eminence, by the thought that a servant of Christ was caught up to the third heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:193
verses.text: For if Elias attained as far as the first heaven, but Paul as far as the third, the latter, therefore, has obtained a more honourable dignity.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:194
verses.text: Be not ashamed of thine Apostles; they are not inferior to Moses, nor second to the Prophets; but they are noble among the noble, yea, nobler still.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:195
verses.text: For Elias truly was taken up into heaven; but Peter has the keys of the kingdom of heaven, having received the words, Whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:196
verses.text: Elias was taken up only to heaven; but Paul both into heaven, and into paradise (for it behoved the disciples of Jesus to receive more manifold grace), and heard unspeakable words, which it is not lawful for man to utter.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:197
verses.text: But Paul came down again from above, not because he was unworthy to abide in the third heaven, but in order that after having enjoyed things above man's reach, and descended in honour, and having preached Christ, and died for His sake, he might receive also the crown of martyrdom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:198
verses.text: But I pass over the other parts of this argument, of which I spoke yesterday in the Lord's-day congregation; for with understanding hearers, a mere reminder is sufficient for instruction.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:200
verses.text: But remember also what I have often said concerning the Son's sitting at the right hand of the Father; because of the next sentence in the Creed, which says, "and ascended into Heaven, and sat down at the right hand of the Father".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:201
verses.text: Let us not curiously pry into what is properly meant by the throne; for it is incomprehensible: but neither let us endure those who falsely say, that it was after His Cross and Resurrection and Ascension into heaven, that the Son began to sit on the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:202
verses.text: For the Son gained not His throne by advancement; but throughout His being (and His being is by an eternal generation) He also sitteth together with the Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:203
verses.text: And this throne the Prophet Esaias having beheld before the incarnate coming of the Saviour, says, I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and lifted up, and the rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:204
verses.text: For the Father no man hath seen at any time, and He who then appeared to the Prophet was the Son.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:205
verses.text: The Psalmist also says, Thy throne is prepared of old; Thou art from everlasting.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:206
verses.text: Though then the testimonies on this point are many, yet because of the lateness of the time, we will content ourselves even with these.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:208
verses.text: But now I must remind you of a few things out of many which are spoken concerning the Son's sitting at the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:209
verses.text: For the hundred and ninth Psalm says plainly, The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou on My right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:210
verses.text: And the Saviour, confirming this saying in the Gospels, says that David spoke not these things of himself, but from the inspiration of the Holy Ghost, saying, How then doth David in the Spirit call Him Lord, saying, The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou on My right hand? and the rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:211
verses.text: And in the Acts of the Apostles, Peter on the day of Pentecost standing with the Eleven, and discoursing to the Israelites, has in very words cited this testimony from the hundred and ninth Psalm.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:213
verses.text: But I must remind you also of a few other testimonies in like manner concerning the Son's sitting at the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:214
verses.text: For in the Gospel according to Matthew it is written, Nevertheless, I say unto you, Henceforth ye shall see the Son of Man sitting on the right hand of power, and the rest: in accordance with which the Apostle Peter also writes, By the Resurrection of Jesus Christ, who is on the right hand of God, having gone into heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:215
verses.text: And the Apostle Paul, writing to the Romans, says, It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:216
verses.text: And charging the Ephesians, he thus speaks, According to the working of His mighty power, which He wrought in Christ when He raised Him from the dead, and set Him at His own right hand; and the rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:217
verses.text: And the Colossians he taught thus, If ye then be risen with Christ, seek the things above, where Christ is seated at the right hand of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:218
verses.text: And in the Epistle to the Hebrews he says, When He had made purification of our sins, He sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:219
verses.text: And again, But unto which of the Angels hath He said at any time, Sit thou at My right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool? And again, But He, when He had offered one sacrifice for all men, for ever sat down on the right hand of God; from henceforth expecting till His enemies be made His footstool.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:220
verses.text: And again, Looking unto Jesus, the author and perfecter of our faith; Who for the joy that was set before Him endured the Cross, despising shame, and is set down on the right hand of the throne of God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:222
verses.text: And though there are many other texts concerning the session of the Only-begotten on the right hand of God, yet these may suffice us at present; with a repetition of my remark, that it was not after His coming in the flesh that He obtained the dignity of this seat; no, for even before all ages, the Only-begotten Son of God, our Lord Jesus Christ, ever possesses the throne on the right hand of the Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:223
verses.text: Now may He Himself, the God of all, who is Father of the Christ, and our Lord Jesus Christ, who came down, and ascended, and sitteth together with the Father, watch over your souls; keep unshaken and unchanged your hope in Him who rose again; raise you together with Him from your dead sins unto His heavenly gift; count you worthy to be caught up in the clouds, to meet the Lord in the air, in His fitting time; and, until that time arrive of His glorious second advent, write all your names in the Book of the living, and having written them, never blot them out (for the names of many, who fall away, are blotted out); and may He grant to all of you to believe on Him who rose again, and to look for Him who is gone up, and is to come again, (to come, but not from the earth; for be on your guard, O man, because of the deceivers who are to come;) Who sitteth on high, and is here present together with us, beholding the order of each, and the steadfastness of his faith.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:224
verses.text: For think not that because He is now absent in the flesh, He is therefore absent also in the Spirit.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 3:225
verses.text: He is here present in the midst of us, listening to what is said of Him, and beholding thine inward thoughts, and trying the reins and hearts;who also is now ready to present those who are coming to baptism, and all of you, in the Holy Ghost to the Father, and to say, Behold, I and the children whom God hath given Me:To whom be glory for ever, Amen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:1
verses.text: Lecture XV.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:2
verses.text: On the Clause, And Shall Come in Glory to Judge the Quick and the Dead; Of Whose Kingdom There Shall Be No End.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:3
verses.text: Daniel vii.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:4
verses.text: 914  I beheld till thrones were placed, and one that was ancient of days did sit, and then, I saw in a vision of the night, and behold one like unto the Son of Man came with the clouds of heaven, &c.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:6
verses.text: We preach not one advent only of Christ, but a second also, far more glorious than the former.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:7
verses.text: For the former gave a view of His patience; but the latter brings with it the crown of a divine kingdom.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:8
verses.text: For all things, for the most part, are twofold in our Lord Jesus Christ: a twofold generation; one, of God, before the ages; and one, of a Virgin, at the close of the ages: His descents twofold; one, the unobserved, like rain on a fleece; and a second His open coming, which is to be.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:9
verses.text: In His former advent, He was wrapped in swaddling clothes in the manger; in His second, He covereth Himself with light as with a garment.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:10
verses.text: In His first coming, He endured the Cross, despising shame; in His second, He comes attended by a host of Angels, receiving glory.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:11
verses.text: We rest not then upon His first advent only, but look also for His second.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 4:12
