verses.text: What he says, is to this effect: Before Thy coming, the evil spirits prepared a table for men, polluted and defiled and full of devilish influence; but since Thy coming.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:26
verses.text: O Lord, Thou hast prepared a table before me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:27
verses.text: When the man says to God, Thou hast prepared before me a table, what other does he indicate but that mystical and spiritual Table, which God hath prepared for us over against, that is, contrary and in opposition to the evil spirits? And very truly; for that had communion with devils, but this, with God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:28
verses.text: Thou hast anointed my head with oil.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:29
verses.text: With oil He anointed thine head upon thy forehead, for the seal which thou hast of God; that thou mayest be made the engraving of the signet, Holiness unto God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:30
verses.text: And thy cup intoxicateth me, as very strong.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:31
verses.text: Thou seest that cup here spoken of, which Jesus took in His hands, and gave thanks, and said, This is My blood, which is shed for many for the remission of sins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:33
verses.text: Therefore Solomon also, hinting at this grace, says in Ecclesiastes, Come hither, eat thy bread with joy (that is, the spiritual bread; Come hither, he calls with the call to salvation and blessing), and drink thy wine with a merry heart (that is, the spiritual wine); and let oil be poured out upon thy head (thou seest he alludes even to the mystic Chrism); and let thy garments be always white, for the Lord is well pleased with thy works; for before thou camest to Baptism, thy works were vanity of vanities.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:34
verses.text: But now, having put off thy old garments, and put on those which are spiritually white, thou must be continually robed in white: of course we mean not this, that thou art always to wear white raiment; but thou must be clad in the garments that are truly white and shining and spiritual, that thou mayest say with the blessed Esaias, My soul shall be joyful in my God; for He hath clothed me with a garment of salvation, and put a robe of gladness around me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:36
verses.text: Having learnt these things, and been fully assured that the seeming bread is not bread, though sensible to taste, but the Body of Christ; and that the seeming wine is not wine, though the taste will have it so, but the Blood of Christ; and that of this David sung of old, saying, And bread strengtheneth man's heart, to make his face to shine with oil, "strengthen thou thine heart," by partaking thereof as spiritual, and "make the face of thy soul to shine".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 11:37
verses.text: And so having it unveiled with a pure conscience, mayest thou reflect as a mirror the glory of the Lord, and proceed from glory to glory, in Christ Jesus our Lord:To whom be honour, and might, and glory, for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:1
verses.text: Lecture XXIII.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:2
verses.text: (On the Mysteries.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:3
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:4
verses.text: )  On the Sacred Liturgy and Communion.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:5
verses.text: 1 Pet.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:6
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:7
verses.text: 1  Wherefore putting away all filthiness, and all guile, and evil speaking, &c.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:9
verses.text: By the loving-kindness of God ye have heard sufficiently at our former meetings concerning Baptism, and Chrism, and partaking of the Body and Blood of Christ; and now it is necessary to pass on to what is next in order, meaning to-day to set the crown on the spiritual building of your edification.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:11
verses.text: Ye have seen then the Deacon who gives to the Priest water to wash, and to the Presbyters who stand round God's altar.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:12
verses.text: He gave it not at all because of bodily defilement; it is not that; for we did not enter the Church at first with defiled bodies.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:13
verses.text: But the washing of hands is a symbol that ye ought to be pure from all sinful and unlawful deeds; for since the hands are a symbol of action, by washing them, it is evident, we represent the purity and blamelessness of our conduct.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:14
verses.text: Didst thou not hear the blessed David opening this very mystery, and saying, I will wash my hands in innocency, and so will compass Thine Altar, O Lord? The washing therefore of hands is a symbol of immunity from sin.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:16
verses.text: Then the Deacon cries aloud, "Receive ye one another; and let us kiss one another".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:17
verses.text: Think not that this kiss is of the same character with those given in public by common friends.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:18
verses.text: It is not such: but this kiss blends souls one with another, and courts entire forgiveness for them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:19
verses.text: The kiss therefore is the sign that our souls are mingled together, and banish all remembrance of wrongs.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:20
verses.text: For this cause Christ said, If thou art offering thy gift at the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath aught against time, leave there thy gift upon the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and offer thy gift.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:21
verses.text: The kiss therefore is reconciliation, and for this reason holy: as the blessed Paul somewhere cried, saying, Greet ye one another with a holy kiss; and Peter, with a kiss of charity.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:23
verses.text: After this the Priest cries aloud, "Lift up your hearts".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:24
verses.text: For truly ought we in that most awful hour to have our heart on high with God, and not below, thinking of earth and earthly things.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:25
verses.text: In effect therefore the Priest bids all in that hour to dismiss all cares of this life, or household anxieties, and to have their heart in heaven with the merciful God.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:26
verses.text: Then ye answer, "We lift them up unto the Lord:" assenting to it, by your avowal.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:27
verses.text: But let no one come here, who could say with his mouth, "We lift up our hearts unto the Lord," but in his thoughts have his mind concerned with the cares of this life.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:28
verses.text: At all times, rather, God should be in our memory but if this is impossible by reason of human infirmity, in that hour above all this should be our earnest endeavour.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:30
verses.text: Then the Priest says, "Let us give thanks unto the Lord".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:31
verses.text: For verily we are bound to give thanks, that He called us, unworthy as we were, to so great grace; that He reconciled us when we were His foes; that He vouchsafed to us the Spirit of adoption.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:32
verses.text: Then ye say, "It is meet and right:" for in giving thanks we do a meet thing and a right; but He did not right, but more than right, in doing us good, and counting us meet for such great benefits.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:34
verses.text: After this, we make mention of heaven, and earth, and sea; of sun and moon; of stars and all the creation, rational and irrational, visible and invisible; of Angels, Archangels, Virtues, Dominions, Principalities, Powers, Thrones; of the Cherubim with many faces: in effect repeating that call of David's Magnify the Lord with me.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:35
verses.text: We make mention also of the Seraphim, whom Esaias in the Holy Spirit saw standing around the throne of God, and with two of their wings veiling their face, and with twain their feet, while with twain they did fly, crying Holy, Holy, Holy, is the Lord of Sabaoth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:36
verses.text: For the reason of our reciting this confession of God, delivered down to us from the Seraphim, is this, that so we may be partakers with the hosts of the world above in their Hymn of praise.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:38
verses.text: Then having sanctified ourselves by these spiritual Hymns, we beseech the merciful God to send forth His Holy Spirit upon the gifts lying before Him; that He may make the Bread the Body of Christ, and the Wine the Blood of Christ; for whatsoever the Holy Ghost has touched, is surely sanctified and changed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:40
verses.text: Then, after the spiritual sacrifice, the bloodless service, is completed, over that sacrifice of propitiation we entreat God for the common peace of the Churches, for the welfare of the world; for kings; for soldiers and allies; for the sick; for the afflicted; and, in a word, for all who stand in need of succour we all pray and offer this sacrifice.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:42
verses.text: Then we commemorate also those who have fallen asleep before us, first Patriarchs, Prophets, Apostles, Martyrs, that at their prayers and intercessions God would receive our petition.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:43
verses.text: Then on behalf also of the Holy Fathers and Bishops who have fallen asleep before us, and in a word of all who in past years have fallen asleep among us, believing that it will be a very great benefit to the souls, for whom the supplication is put up, while that holy and most awful sacrifice is set forth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:45
verses.text: And I wish to persuade you by an illustration.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:46
verses.text: For I know that many say, what is a soul profited, which departs from this world either with sins, or without sins, if it be commemorated in the prayer? For if a king were to banish certain who had given him offence, and then those who belong to them should weave a crown and offer it to him on behalf of those under punishment, would he not grant a remission of their penalties? In the same way we, when we offer to Him our supplications for those who have fallen asleep, though they be sinners, weave no crown, but offer up Christ sacrificed for our sins, propitiating our merciful God for them as well as for ourselves.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:48
verses.text: Then, after these things, we say that Prayer which the Saviour delivered to His own disciples, with a pure conscience entitling God our Father, and saying, Our Father, which art in heaven.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:49
verses.text: O most surpassing loving-kindness of God! On them who revolted from Him and were in the very extreme of misery has He bestowed such a complete forgiveness of evil deeds, and so great participation of grace, as that they should even call Him Father.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:50
verses.text: Our Father, which art in heaven; and they also are a heaven who bear the image of the heavenly, in whom is God, dwelling and walking in them.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:52
verses.text: Hallowed be Thy Name.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:53
verses.text: The Name of God is in its nature holy, whether we say so or not; but since it is sometimes profaned among sinners, according to the words, Through you My Name is continually blasphemed among the Gentiles, we pray that in us God's Name may be hallowed; not that it comes to be holy from not being holy, but because it becomes holy in us, when we are made holy, and do things worthy of holiness.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:55
verses.text: Thy kingdom come.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:56
verses.text: A pure soul can say with boldness, Thy kingdom come; for he who has heard Paul saying, Let not therefore sin reign in your mortal body, and has cleansed himself in deed, and thought, and word, will say to God, Thy kingdom come.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:58
verses.text: Thy will be done as in heaven so on earth.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:59
verses.text: God's divine and blessed Angels do the will of God, as David said in the Psalm, Bless the Lord, all ye Angels of His, mighty in strength, that do His pleasure.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:60
verses.text: So then in effect thou meanest this by thy prayer, "as in the Angels Thy will is done, so likewise be it done on earth in me, O Lord".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:62
verses.text: Give us this day our substantial bread.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:63
verses.text: This common bread is not substantial bread, but this Holy Bread is substantial, that is, appointed for the substance of the soul.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:64
verses.text: For this Bread goeth not into the belly and is cast out into the draught, but is distributed into thy whole system for the benefit of body and soul.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:65
verses.text: But by this day, he means, "each day," as also Paul said, While it is called to-day.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:67
verses.text: And forgive us our debts as we also forgive our debtors.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:68
verses.text: For we have many sins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:69
verses.text: For we offend both in word and in thought, and very many things we do worthy of condemnation; and if we say that we have no sin, we lie, as John says.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:70
verses.text: And we make a covenant with God, entreating Him to forgive us our sins, as we also forgive our neighbours their debts.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:71
verses.text: Considering then what we receive and in return for what, let us not put off nor delay to forgive one another.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:72
verses.text: The offences committed against us are slight and trivial, and easily settled; but those which we have committed against God are great, and need such mercy as His only is.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:73
verses.text: Take heed therefore, lest for the slight and trivial sins against thee thou shut out for thyself forgiveness from God for thy very grievous sins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:75
verses.text: And lead us not into temptation, O Lord.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:76
verses.text: Is this then what the Lord teaches us to pray, that we may not be tempted at all? How then is it said elsewhere, "a man untempted, is a man unproved;" and again, My brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations? But does perchance the entering into temptation mean the being overwhelmed by the temptation? For temptation is, as it were, like a winter torrent difficult to cross.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:77
verses.text: Those therefore who are not overwhelmed in temptations, pass through, shewing themselves excellent swimmers, and not being swept away by them at all; while those who are not such, enter into them and are overwhelmed.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:78
verses.text: As for example, Judas having entered into the temptation of the love of money, swam not through it, but was overwhelmed and was strangled both in body and spirit.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:79
verses.text: Peter entered into the temptation of the denial; but having entered, he was not overwhelmed by it, but manfully swam through it, and was delivered from the temptation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:80
verses.text: Listen again, in another place, to a company of unscathed saints, giving thanks for deliverance from temptation, Thou, O God hast proved us; Thou hast tried us by fire like as silver is tried.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:81
verses.text: Thou broughtest us into the net; Thou layedst afflictions upon our loins.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:82
verses.text: Thou hast caused men to ride over our heads; we went through fire and water; and thou broughtest us out into a place of rest.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:83
verses.text: Thou seest them speaking boldly in regard to their having passed through and not been pierced.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:84
verses.text: But Thou broughtest us out into a place of rest; now their coming into a place of rest is their being delivered from temptation.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:86
verses.text: But deliver us from the evil.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:87
verses.text: If Lead us not into temptation implied the not being tempted at all, He would not have said, But deliver us from the evil.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:88
verses.text: Now evil is our adversary the devil, from whom we pray to be delivered.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:89
verses.text: Then after completing the prayer thou sayest, Amen; by this Amen, which means "So be it," setting thy seal to the petitions of the divinely-taught prayer.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:91
verses.text: After this the Priest says, "Holy things to holy men".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:92
verses.text: Holy are the gifts presented, having received the visitation of the Holy Ghost; holy are ye also, having been deemed worthy of the Holy Ghost; the holy things therefore correspond to the holy persons.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:93
verses.text: Then ye say, "One is Holy, One is the Lord, Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:94
verses.text: For One is truly holy, by nature holy; we too are holy, but not by nature, only by participation, and discipline, and prayer.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:96
verses.text: After this ye hear the chanter inviting you with a sacred melody to the communion of the Holy Mysteries, and saying, O taste and see that the Lord is good.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:97
verses.text: Trust not the judgment to thy bodily palate no, but to faith unfaltering; for they who taste are bidden to taste, not bread and wine, but the anti-typical Body and Blood of Christ.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:99
verses.text: In approaching therefore, come not with thy wrists extended, or thy fingers spread; but make thy left hand a throne for the right, as for that which is to receive a King.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:100
verses.text: And having hollowed thy palm, receive the Body of Christ, saying over it, Amen.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:101
verses.text: So then after having carefully hallowed thine eyes by the touch of the Holy Body, partake of it; giving heed lest thou lose any portion thereof; for whatever thou losest, is evidently a loss to thee as it were from one of thine own members.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:102
verses.text: For tell me, if any one gave thee grains of gold, wouldest thou not hold them with all carefulness, being on thy guard against losing any of them, and suffering loss? Wilt thou not then much more carefully keep watch, that not a crumb fall from thee of what is more precious than gold and precious stones?  22.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:103
verses.text: Then after thou hast partaken of the Body of Christ, draw near also to the Cup of His Blood; not stretching forth thine hands, but bending, and saying with an air of worship and reverence, Amen, hallow thyself by partaking also of the Blood of Christ.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:104
verses.text: And while the moisture is still upon thy lips, touch it with thine hands, and hallow thine eyes and brow and the other organs of sense.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:105
verses.text: Then wait for the prayer, and give thanks unto God, who hath accounted thee worthy of so great mysteries.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:107
verses.text: Hold fast these traditions undefiled and, keep yourselves free from offence.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:108
verses.text: Sever not yourselves from the Communion; deprive not yourselves, through the pollution of sins, of these Holy and Spiritual Mysteries.

verses.name: Cyril: Catechal Lectures II 12:109
verses.text: And the God of peace sanctify you wholly; and may your spirit, and soul, and body be preserved entire without blame at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ:To whom be glory and honour and might, with the Father and the Holy Spirit, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.
